title: Litchfield Beaches Property Owners Association v. Cerasaro
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Litchfield Beaches Property Owners Association,
Appellant,
v.
The Thomas S. Cerasaro Qualified Personal Residence Trust Dated December 28, 2000,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-236Â Â Â 
Heard April 5, 2006 â€“ Filed May 9, 2006 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Jack M. Scoville, Jr., of Georgetown, for Appellant.
Robert J. Moran, of Murrells Inlet, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The Litchfield Beaches Property Owners Association (Litchfield) brought this action alleging Thomas S. Cerasaro[1] constructed an addition to his oceanfront home in violation of a restrictive covenant establishing a setback line.Â  The trial court granted partial summary judgment to Cerasaro â€œon the issue of the location of the setback line on his property as being measured one hundred (100â€™) feet from the mean [high-water] mark of the Atlantic Ocean.â€Â  Litchfield appeals.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Litchfield is an unincorporated property ownersâ€™ association vested with the authority to enforce the restrictive covenants applicable to lots in the North Litchfield Beach subdivision in Georgetown County.Â  Cerasaro owns an oceanfront home on Lot 14, Section A of the subdivision.Â  Litchfield alleges Cerasaro constructed an addition to his home that violates a restrictive covenant establishing an oceanfront setback.Â  The parties dispute the actual location of the setback line.
The property Cerasaro now owns was once part of a larger, 45-acreÂ  parcel purchased by North Litchfield Beach, Inc. from the Boyle family in 1959.Â  The deed to North Litchfield Beach, Inc. referred to a May 1959 plat prepared by Samuel M. Harper, R.L.S. and described the property by courses and distances, e.g., â€œto the Atlantic Ocean; thence along the high[-]water mark of the Atlantic Ocean 6701 feet to the line of lands of International Paper Company,â€ and by metes and bounds, e.g., â€œButting and Bounding to the North by lands of Brook Green Gardens, to the East and Southeast by the Atlantic Ocean.â€Â  Thus, the deed to North Litchfield Beach, Inc. conveyed the property to the high-water mark of the Atlantic Ocean.Â Â Â Â Â  
The deed excepted certain lots that the Boyle family had previously platted and sold.Â  All of the lots previously sold by the Boyle family, however, contained an area between the eastern boundary line and the Atlantic Ocean that was labeled, â€œSand Dunes.â€Â  These lots apparently were not conveyed to the high-water mark of the Atlantic Ocean.Â  
North Litchfield Beach, Inc. caused a subsequent subdivision plat, prepared by Samuel M. Harper dated December 1959 (the â€œHarper Platâ€), to be recorded.Â  This document completed the subdivision of the property purchased from the Boyle family into multiple single-family lots.Â  The Harper Plat is filed in Plat Book O at Page 4.Â  
On January 22, 1960, North Litchfield Beach, Inc. conveyed Lot 14, Section A, the lot at issue here, to George Rowe Townsend.Â  The deed describes Lot 14-A as follows:

That certain lot of land situate, lying and being in the County of Georgetown and State of South Carolina, designated as Lot Number FOURTEEN (14) of SECTION A, on a Map of North Litchfield Beach made by Samuel M. Harper, R.L.S., dated December 1959, recorded in the office of the Clerk of Court for Georgetown County in Plat Book O, page 4.Â  

This deed contains neither courses and distances, nor metes and bounds.Â  It does, however, contain a list of fifteen enumerated restrictions.Â  Restriction seven provides in pertinent part as follows:

7.Â  The residence constructed on this lot, including porches or projections, shall not be erected nearer than 100 feet from highwater mark as shown on map, nor nearer than 5 feet to either side boundary lot, nor nearer than 25 feet to the rear line thereof, except in the event two (2) lots are purchased for the purpose of erecting thereon one single family dwelling the dividing line between said lots shall not be considered as a side line.Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  

On the Harper Plat, Book O at Page 4, Lot 14-A is depicted as a rectangle measuring 70 feet on the front and rear and 200 feet on both sides.Â  The front of the property faces west and borders Seaview Loop.Â  The rear of the property faces east and is bounded by a legend that says, â€œAtlantic Ocean.â€Â  The words â€œhigh-water markâ€ do not appear anywhere on the Harper Plat.Â  
Cerasaro acquired Lot 14-A, including a residence, from Albert H. Agett in 1987.Â  The deed contained the same general description as noted in the 1960 Townsend deed.Â  It similarly provides neither courses and distances, nor metes and bounds.Â Â Â  
In 2004, Cerasaro began construction of an addition to his home that extended to within 119 feet of the high-water mark of the Atlantic Ocean as it then existed.Â  Such improvements, however, extended beyond the boundary line fronting the Atlantic Ocean as drawn on the Harper Plat.Â  As a result, Litchfield brought this action alleging Cerasaroâ€™s construction violated the setback line and sought removal of the encroachment.Â  The parties disputed whether the setback line is to be measured from the undesignated line shown on the Harper Plat or whether it is to be measured from the mean high-water mark as it currently exists.[2]  
Cerasaro moved for summary judgment and Litchfield moved for partial summary judgment.Â  The trial court found the restriction was ambiguous, but resolved the ambiguity in favor of the free use of the property and granted partial summary judgment in favor of Cerasaro.Â  The court found for Cerasaro as a matter of law â€œon the issue of the location of the setback line on his property as being measured one hundred (100â€™) feet from the mean [high-water] mark of the Atlantic Ocean.â€Â  The court did not rule on the remaining issues of laches, waiver, and selective enforcement that were raised by the parties, noting those issues involved factual findings.Â Â  Litchfield appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Under the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, summary judgment is appropriate only â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.â€Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002); see also Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 529, 511 S.E.2d 69, 74 (1999) (â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€).Â  
â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Ambiguity of Restriction
Litchfield first argues the trial court erred in ruling the deed restriction is ambiguous.Â  Litchfield contends that, to the contrary, the restriction is unambiguous because the boundary line fronting the Atlantic Ocean on the Harper Plat clearly establishes the high-water mark as of December 1959 and thus permanently fixes the setback line as being 100 feet from that point.Â  We disagree.
A contract is ambiguous when the terms of the contract are reasonably susceptible of more than one interpretation.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Resources v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 550 S.E.2d 299 (2001).Â  Moreover, â€œ â€˜[a] contract is ambiguous when it is capable of more than one meaning when viewed objectively by a reasonably intelligent person who has examined the context of the entire integrated agreement and who is cognizant of the customs, practices, usages and terminology as generally understood in the particular trade or business.â€™ â€Â  Hawkins v. Greenwood Dev. Corp., 328 S.C. 585, 592, 493 S.E.2d 875, 878 (Ct. App. 1997) (quoting 17A Am. Jur. 2d Contracts Â§ 339 (1991)).
In this case, the deed restriction creates an ocean setback line at the â€œhigh[-]water mark as shown on map.â€Â  The problem is, however, that the Harper Plat referenced in the deed does not contain any notation as to where the high-water mark is located.Â  There is a line on the Harper Plat that ends along a line 200 feet from Seaview Loop, which could indicate the depth of the lot.Â  On the other hand, the notation on the other side of the line is â€œAtlantic Ocean.â€Â  Thus, it is unclear whether this line merely marks the edge of the property or if it is meant to be the high-water mark as of the time the Harper Plat was made in December 1959.Â  
The trial court found the restriction is ambiguous because the setback could be measured either from the usual high tide of the ocean or from the line purportedly showing the property border on the 1959 survey.Â  The trial court granted partial summary judgment to Cerasaro, ruling any ambiguity must be resolved in favor of the free use of property, thus the proper interpretation, as a matter of law, is that the deed refers to the mean high-water mark as it exists today.
In our opinion, the parties cannot determine, without resort to extrinsic evidence, where the high-water mark existed at the time the restriction was created and where it is supposed to be on the map.Â  Moreover, even if the line were clearly marked on the map, there is further ambiguity as to whether the parties intended the setback line to be 100 feet from the high-water mark as it existed in 1959, thus creating a permanent setback, or whether it was to be interpreted as restricting construction closer than 100 feet to the high-water mark as it exists at the point of construction, as the mean high-water mark is subject to fluctuation over the years.Â  Therefore, we hold the trial court properly determined the deed restriction is ambiguous.Â  
II.Â  Propriety of Granting Partial Summary Judgment
Litchfield further argues that, in the event we uphold the trial courtâ€™s determination that the restriction is ambiguous, the trial court erred in resolving that ambiguity as a matter of law and granting partial summary judgment in favor of Cerasaro regarding the location of the setback line.Â  We agree.
â€œThe construction and enforcement of an unambiguous contract is a question of law for the court, and thus can be properly disposed of at summary judgment.â€Â  Middleborough Horizontal Property Regime Council of Co-Owners v. Montedison
S.p.A., 320 S.C. 470, 477, 465 S.E.2d 765, 770 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œIn such a case, summary judgment is proper and a trial unnecessary where the intention of the parties as to the legal effect of the contract may be gathered from the four corners of the instrument itself.â€Â  First-Citizens Bank & Trust Co. v. Conway Natâ€™l Bank, 282 S.C. 303, 305, 317 S.E.2d 776, 777 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Â 
If, on the other hand, a contract is ambiguous or capable of more than one construction, the question of what the parties intended becomes one of fact and should, therefore, be decided by the trier of fact.Â  Middleborough, 320 S.C. at 477, 465 S.E.2d at 770.Â  â€œOnce a contract is before the court for interpretation, the paramount concern of the court is to give effect to the intention of the parties.â€Â  Id.  
In this case, the trial court found â€œ[t]he actual location of the oceanfront setback applicable to [Cerasaroâ€™s] property is either measured from the high[-]water mark of the Atlantic Ocean or the most easterly line shown on the original 1959 subdivision plat [the Harper Plat].â€Â  Having found such an ambiguity, the trial court erred in resolving it as a matter of law.Â  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Resources v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 623, 550 S.E.2d 299, 303 (2001) (When construing a restrictive covenant, â€œ[o]nce the court decides the language is ambiguous, evidence may be admitted to show the intent of the parties.Â  The determination of the partiesâ€™ intent is then a question of fact.â€).Â  
Cerasaro asserts the trial court properly applied South Carolina case law by resolving the ambiguity as a matter of law in favor of the grantee and the free use of property.Â  We disagree.
In Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. at 622, 550 S.E.2d at 302, our supreme court stated:Â  â€œ â€˜It is still the settled rule in this jurisdiction that restrictions as to the use of real estate should be strictly construed and all doubts resolved in favor of free use of the property, subject, however, to the provision that this rule of strict construction should not be applied so as to defeat the plain and obvious purpose of the instrument.â€™ â€Â  (quoting Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 4, 498 S.E.2d 862, 864 (1998)) (alteration in original).
â€œ â€˜The purpose of all rules of construction is to ascertain the intention of the parties to the contract.â€™ â€Â  Hansen v. United Servs. Auto. Assâ€™n, 350 S.C. 62, 68, 565 S.E.2d 114, 116 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Bruce v. Blalock, 241 S.C. 155, 161, 127 S.E.2d 439, 442 (1962)).Â  â€œResort may be had to rules of construction only where the language of the instrument, or of a portion thereof, is of doubtful or uncertain meaning, or is ambiguous or contradictory.â€Â  17A C.J.S. Contracts Â§ 303 (1999).Â  â€œ[W]here the terms are ambiguous, the question of the partiesâ€™ intent must be submitted to the [trier of fact].â€Â  Hansen, 350 S.C. at 68, 565 S.E.2d at 116.
While the trial court correctly recognized Town of McClellanville favors construing the restrictive covenant here in favor of Cerasaro, under these circumstances we hold the trial court prematurely applied this rule of construction.Â  Once the trial court ruled the provision was ambiguous, the parties should have been allowed to present evidence as to the partiesâ€™ intent or the plain and obvious purpose of the restriction as these issues presented questions of fact that were not appropriate for determination as a matter of law on summary judgment.Â  See Hook v. Rothstein, 275 S.C. 187, 189, 268 S.E.2d 288, 289 (1980) (â€œThis court has often noted that summary judgment is appropriate only where it is perfectly clear that no genuine issue of fact is involved and inquiry into the facts is not desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€); 17B C.J.S. Contracts Â§ 743 (1999) (â€œEvidence as to the intention of the parties is relevant only if the contract in issue is ambiguous.Â  . . .Â  [I]n determining such intention the court may receive parol, or extrinsic evidence.Â  Extrinsic evidence in ascertaining the partiesâ€™ intent includes:Â  (1) the situation of the parties at the time the instrument was executed; (2) the circumstances under which the instrument was executed; and (3) the subsequent conduct of the contracting parties.â€).Â  Accordingly, we reverse the grant of partial summary judgment to Cerasaro and remand for further proceedings.[3]
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  This action was brought against the â€œThomas S. Cerasaro Qualified Personal Residence Trust Dated December 28, 2000,â€ but for purposes of this opinion we shall refer to the defendant/respondent as Thomas Cerasaro or simply, Cerasaro. 
[2]Â  If the setback is measured from the line shown as the eastern boundary of Cerasaroâ€™s lot on the Harper Plat, i.e., the line that is 200 feet from Seaview Loop, then Cerasaroâ€™s home addition is, admittedly, inside the setback line.Â  If the setback is measured from the current mean high-water mark, however, the addition definitely is not in violation of the restriction.Â  The trial court noted the mean high-water mark of the Atlantic Ocean as of March 24, 2004 was between 245 feet and 253 feet from Seaview Loop.Â Â Â  
[3]Â  To the extent Litchfield also asserts on appeal that the trial court erred in failing to grant its motion for partial summary judgment, we find this question is not properly before us as the failure to grant a motion for summary judgment is not appealable.Â  Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476, 443 S.E.2d 379 (1994) (stating the denial of summary judgment is not directly appealable, even after final judgment, because it does not finally determine the merits of the case).

title: SCDOT v. McDonald's Corporation
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Transportation, Respondent,
v.
McDonald's Corporation and Joel A. Pellicci and Linda
Pellicci, of whom McDonald's Corporation is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-237
Heard March 7, 2006 â€“ Filed May 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael H. Quinn, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Barbara Munig Wessinger, of Columbia, Larry B. Hyman, Jr., of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  McDonaldâ€™s Corporation (McDonaldâ€™s) appeals an Horry County administrative judgeâ€™s order granting the South Carolina Department of Transportationâ€™s (SCDOTâ€™s) motion in limine regarding evidence of damages arising from a prior condemnation action.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
McDonaldâ€™s owns property (the Property) in Horry County fronting the southern side of Waccamaw Boulevard (Waccamaw), a road which previously accessed Highway 501 (501) directly.Â  McDonaldâ€™s operates a restaurant on the Property, which rests a short distance from the Waccamaw Pottery Complex.
To improve traffic flow in the area, SCDOT decided to reconfigure the frontage road system along 501 near the Property.Â  Part of this reconfiguration included a change in access from Waccamaw to 501.Â  Instead of directly accessing 501, Waccamaw would connect to the new frontage road system and access 501 through a more circuitous route.Â  To complete the project, SCDOT also needed to acquire certain portions of the McDonaldâ€™s property.Â  Toni P. Elliott, SCDOTâ€™s right of way agent, contacted John Amendola, an employee of McDonaldâ€™s real estate department, to discuss the acquisition of portions of the Property, including 4,372 square feet fronting Bush Drive and a smaller strip of land abutting George Bishop Parkway.
Robert M. Christopher, a licensed real estate appraiser hired by SCDOT, appraised the value of the Property both before and after SCDOTâ€™s proposed acquisition.Â  The appraisal specifically noted the remainder of the Property would â€œgenerally be the same . . . however, in the after situation, the access will change.â€Â  The appraisal indicated that the frontage road systemâ€™s reconfiguration would probably result in a net benefit to McDonaldâ€™s.Â  Christopher ultimately estimated the difference in the Propertyâ€™s value after the 1999 acquisition to be $42,800.
Elliott contacted Amendola, explained the results of SCDOTâ€™s appraisals, and offered McDonaldâ€™s $42,800 for the contemplated portion of the Property.Â  This offer is memorialized in a letter from Elliott dated February 3, 1998.Â  For approximately a year following the offer, the parties exchanged phone calls regarding the acquisition and the necessary relocation of the restaurantâ€™s sign.Â  Unable to come to terms on a definitive agreement on the signâ€™s relocation, SCDOT initiated condemnation proceedings (the 1999 condemnation) on February 18, 1999.
The 1999 condemnation notice describes SCDOTâ€™s acquisition as fee simple title to 4,372 square feet of land â€œ[w]ithin 55 feet of the survey centerline of Frontage Road 6F [formerly Bush Drive], on the left . . . Also herein condemned is property within 45 feet of the survey centerline of George Bishop Parkway, on the right . . . .â€ On March 8, 1999, Sandy Ligon, an employee of McDonaldâ€™s, contacted Elliott about the condemnation notice and indicated she â€œwanted to see if [they] could work the situation out without going to court.â€Â  As a result, the parties settled the 1999 condemnation action.
On March 23, 1999, McDonaldâ€™s executed a deed to SCDOT reciting consideration of $42,800 for the proposed portion of the Property.Â  The deed also expressly called for the relocation of the restaurantâ€™s sign.Â  Shortly thereafter, the parties executed a stipulation of dismissal with respect to the pending condemnation action, reciting that â€œthis case has been settled and, therefore, should be ended and stricken from the calendar . . . .â€
In 2000, SCDOT revised the plans for 501, deciding to elevate the highway and allow George Bishop Parkway to run underneath it.Â  As a result, SCDOT initiated a second condemnation proceeding against McDonaldâ€™s (the 2000 condemnation) to obtain an additional 520 square feet of land and â€œrights of access as may be needed for controlled access facilities.â€Â  On December 15, 2003, SCDOT filed a motion in limine requesting the court to exclude any reference to the change in access from Waccamaw to 501, arguing that this change was contemplated in the 1999 condemnation settlement and had no bearing on the current proceedings.Â  McDonaldâ€™s responded with it own motion, asking the court to prevent SCDOT from presenting evidence that McDonaldâ€™s had already received compensation for Waccamawâ€™s change in highway access.
After a hearing on the motions, a special administrative judge for the Horry County condemnation roster issued an order granting SCDOTâ€™s motion and denying McDonaldâ€™s.Â  This appeal followed the denial of McDonaldâ€™s motion to reconsider.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe admission of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial judge, and absent a clear abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law, the trial courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal.â€Â  Vaught v. A.O. Hardee & Sons, Inc., 366 S.C. 475, 480, 623 S.E.2d 373, 375 (2005).
DISCUSSION
McDonaldâ€™s contends the circuit court erred in concluding the change in access from Waccamaw to 501 was contemplated in the 1999 settlement and, thus, not relevant to the present condemnation action.Â  We disagree.
A motion in limine may be used in civil matters â€œto gain a ruling excluding evidence which is irrelevant.â€Â  75 Am. Jur. 2d Trials Â§ 102 (Supp. 2005).Â  â€œThe compensable measure of damages [in a condemnation proceeding is] the value of the land at the date of the taking plus any resulting injury to the remaining property offset by any benefits to the remaining land as a result of the project.â€Â  South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t v. Carodale Assocs., 268 S.C. 556, 563, 235 S.E.2d 127, 130 (1977) (emphasis added).Â  McDonaldâ€™s, therefore, must show that the damages from the change in access resulted from the present condemnation or were not contemplated in the 1999 settlement for evidence of such to be relevant to the present action.
It is uncontested that the alteration in access from Waccamaw to 501 did not result from the elevation of 501 over George Bishop Parkway.Â  McDonaldâ€™s instead bases it argument on whether the access alterations were contemplated in the 1999 settlement.Â  Settlement agreements are viewed as contracts between the parties.Â  Harris-Jenkins v. Nissan Car Mart, Inc., 348 S.C. 171, 177, 557 S.E.2d 708, 711 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAn action to construe a contract is an action at law reviewable under an â€˜any evidenceâ€™ standard.â€Â  Pruitt v. South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liability Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 343 S.C. 335, 339, 540 S.E.2d 843, 845 (2001).
SCDOT submitted the affidavit of J. Williams Gobbel, a licensed professional engineer, to support its position the construction plans attached to Christopherâ€™s appraisal and sent to McDonaldâ€™s clearly show Waccamaw would no longer directly access 501.Â  Furthermore, Christopherâ€™s appraisal expressly indicated the change in access to the Property would not result in any pecuniary loss to McDonaldâ€™s.Â  The affidavit of McDonaldâ€™s professional engineer also notably admits that an experienced professional could discern from the plans that access from Waccamaw to 501 would be reconfigured by the initial project plans.Â  In addition, Elliottâ€™s records indicate she discussed the change in access with Amendola and he agreed the change in access could benefit McDonaldâ€™s in the long run.Â  Elliottâ€™s affidavit stated she commenced discussion with McDonaldâ€™s regarding the change in highway access as early as 1994, over four years prior to the 1999 settlement.[1]
Because there is evidence supporting the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion that any damages arising from the alteration of Waccamawâ€™s access to 501 were contemplated in the 1999 settlement, we conclude the circuit court did not err in excluding evidence of these damages from the current proceedings as irrelevant.Â  We briefly address the following arguments also presented by McDonaldâ€™s on appeal:
I. South Carolina Code Section 28-2-280(C)(3)
McDonaldâ€™s argues section 28-2-280(C)(3) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) required SCDOT to include the change in access from Waccamaw to 501 in its 1999 condemnation notice.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe Condemnation Notice must . . . contain an appropriate legal description of the property to be taken or out of which an interest will be taken, and of the interest to be taken . . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-280(C)(3) (1991).Â  However, â€œ[a]t any time before or after commencement of an action, the parties may agree to and carry out, according to its terms, a compromise or settlement as to any matter, including all or any part of the compensation or other relief.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-40 (1991).
In the 1999 settlement, the parties clearly took advantage of section 28-2-40 and entered into a settlement of the condemnation action.Â  Therefore, whether SCDOT complied with the notice requirements of section 28-2-280 (C)(3) is immaterial to the present action when the circuit court determines the change in highway access was contemplated by the prior settlement.
II. The Merger Doctrine
McDonaldâ€™s asserts the deed should have been the only evidence relied upon by the circuit court to determine the terms of the 1999 settlement.Â  We disagree.
Generally, â€œa deed made in full execution of a contract of sale of land merges the provisions of the contract therein, and . . . this rule extends to and includes all prior negotiations and agreements leading up to the execution of the deed.â€Â  Charleston & W.C. Ry. Co. v. Joyce, 231 S.C. 493, 504, 99 S.E.2d 187, 193 (1957) (internal citations omitted).Â  However, when â€œa deed constitutes only part performance of a preceding contract, other distinct and unperformed provisions of the contract are not merged in the deed.â€Â  New Prospect Area Fire Dist. v. New Prospect Ruritan Club, 311 S.C. 402, 405, 429 S.E.2d 791, 792 (1993).
In the present case, the circuit court concluded the deed was not the partiesâ€™ final agreement with respect to the 1999 condemnation, but was only the partial performance of the preceding settlement agreement.Â  The evidence supports this finding.Â  The deed was executed in March 1999, but the stipulation of dismissal, clearly a part of the settlement agreement, was not included in the deedâ€™s terms.Â  We conclude, therefore, that the circuit court did not err in considering evidence outside the deed in determining the terms of the 1999 settlement.
III. The Effect of the Stipulation of Dismissal
McDonaldâ€™s contends the effect of the stipulation of dismissal without prejudice was to void the 1999 condemnation notice and the resulting proceedings.Â  This issue is not germane to the present appeal.Â  After SCDOT filed a notice of condemnation, the parties entered into a settlement of the condemnation action.Â  The circuit court concluded this settlement contemplated the change in access from Waccamaw to 501.Â  The circuit court did not determine that the action was barred by concepts of res judicata, thus, the court did not misconstrue the dismissalâ€™s legal consequence.
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â Â Â  

[1] McDonaldâ€™s contends the circuit erred in addressing disputed facts in a motion in limine.Â  This issue is not properly preserved for our review.Â  See Long v. Norris & Assocs., Ltd., 342 S.C. 561, 578, 538 S.E.2d 5, 14 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œTo properly preserve an issue for review, the litigant must make a contemporaneous objection.â€)

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services,
Respondent,
v.
Marggie Hutson, Eliseo Perez, and Landin Naun PerezÂ  DOB: 08/29/02, Minor under the age of 18 years, Defendants, of whom Marggie Hutson and Eliseo Perez are
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Â James A. Spruill, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-238
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 15, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Bryan W. Braddock, of Florence, for Secondary Appellant.
Marggie Hutson, pro se, for Primary Appellant.
Newton Howle, Jr., of Darlington, for Respondent.
Robbie Forrester Gardner, III, of Hartsville, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this termination of parental rights (TPR) action, Marggie Hutson and Eliseo Perez appeal a family court ruling terminating their parental rights.Â  Hutsonâ€™s attorney filed an affidavit pursuant to Ex parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), in which she states that Hutsonâ€™s appeal is without merit.Â  Hutson filed a response detailing her position and arguing the appeal is not without merit.Â  Perez is represented by counsel on appeal and submitted a standard brief.
The Appellantsâ€™ child was taken into emergency protective custody on May 6, 2003, and has remained in custody since that time.Â  On June 10, 2003, a merits hearing was held and resulted in a finding of physical neglect against Hutson.Â  Although treatment plans were
implemented, neither Hutson nor Perez made any substantial progress towards completion.Â  In addition, neither of the parents paid support for the child and although Perez brought the child meals and gifts when he visited, his visits were sporadicâ€”at times being several months apart.Â  Perez attempted to complete the treatment plan a second time, but tested positive for cocaine use twice in January 2005. Â Appellant Hutson is currently incarcerated and is expected to be released in January 2007.Â  We affirm.
â€œIn a termination of parental rights (TPR) case, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.â€Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 287 (Ct. App. 2000)).Â  Before a parentâ€™s rights may be terminated, the alleged grounds for termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Mrs. H, 346 S.C. 329, 333, 550 S.E.2d 898, 901 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination of whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id.; see also South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, despite this broad scope of review, this court is not required to disregard the findings of the family court nor ignore the fact that the trial judge was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  This is especially true in cases involving the welfare of children.Â  Aiken County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilcox, 304 S.C. 90, 93, 403 S.E.2d 142, 144 (Ct. App. 1991).
Under South Carolinaâ€™s termination of parental rights statute, â€œ[t]he family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the [listed] grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).Â  If the family court finds a statutory ground for termination has been proven, it must then find the best interests of the children would be served by termination.Â  Id.Â Â  Significantly, as our supreme court has noted and the TPR statute provides: â€œTPR statutes â€˜must be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by terminating the parent[-]child relationship.â€™â€Â  Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 108, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000) (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 1999)).
In the current case, after considering all the evidence, the family court ruled that Appellantsâ€™ parental rights should be terminated based on several different grounds.Â  As to both Appellants, the court found: (1) The child has lived outside the home for a period of six months and during this time the parents have willfully failed to visit the child.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (3) (Supp. 2005); (2) The child has been in foster care for 15 of the most recent 22 months.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (8) (Supp. 2005); and (3) Termination would be in the childâ€™s best interests.Â  Doe, 353 S.C. at 579, 578 S.E.2d at 735.Â  The family court further found as to Hutson that she â€œfailed to remedy the conditions which caused the removal of the Defendant child or to rehabilitate.â€Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (2) (Supp. 2005).
After carefully considering the record and the arguments submitted by the parties and reviewing it pursuant to Ex parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), we find the family court did not err in terminating the Appellantsâ€™ parental rights.Â Â  There is sufficient evidence in the record for us to conclude that the family courtâ€™s rulings are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Therefore, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision and grant Hutsonâ€™s counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.Â  
AFFIRMED.[1]
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Stewart v. Flynn
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Walter Dan Stewart, Appellant,
v.
Kevin N. Flynn, individually and d/b/a Flynn Construction,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-240
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 15, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephen R.H. Lewis, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Eric K. Englebardt, and Jennifer D. Eubanks, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this appeal from an automobile accident negligence case, Dan Stewart claims the trial judge erred in admitting evidence that violated the collateral source rule.Â  Stewart also alleges the jury verdict with respect to damages was affected by this error and his motion for a new trial nisi additur should have been granted.Â  
FACTS
On April 6, 2000, Dan Stewart was involved in an automobile accident with Kevin Flynn, the owner of Flynn Construction Company. Â At trial, Flynn admitted negligence and left damages as the only issue to be determined at trial.Â  Flynn was driving a company truck when he ran into the back of Stewartâ€™s automobile.Â  At this time neither Stewart nor Flynn required medical Â attention. Â Emergency personnel did, however, transport Stewartâ€™s passenger to the hospital for treatment.Â  
Later, when Stewart went to the hospital to visit the passenger, he requested medical attention for pain in his right wrist, right arm, and neck. Â The hospital found no broken bones and did not diagnose any head trauma.[1]Â  Stewart had a history of back pain and sought treatment for that pain before the accident. Â Ultimately Dr. John Haasis, a physiatrist, testified that Stewart suffered a 10% permanent impairment of his lower back as a result of the accident.Â  
Some time after the accident, Stewart began to experience some facial pains.Â  Stewart described the pain as a ticking pain at first eventually turning into a constant and excruciating pain. Â In August of 2000, Stewartâ€™s family physician referred him to Dr. Jerry Sherrill, a neurologist, who diagnosed Stewart with trigeminal neuralgia. Â Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition resulting from inflammation of the trigeminal nerve, which causes severe, shock-like pain in the face.Â  Stewart underwent a procedure called a trigeminal rhizotomy, which is intended to burn the abnormally conducting sensory fibers of the nerve without affecting the portion of the nerve that controls motor function. Â Stewart temporarily lost the ability to move his right eye and permanently lost the ability of his tear ducts to naturally lubricate his right eye. 
The two main issues at trial were the cause of Stewartâ€™s injuries and the damages stemming from them.Â  Both parties used expert testimony to support their claims.Â  Stewart alleged losses related to his past and future medical bills, past and future lost wages, and pain and suffering.Â  The jury returned a verdict in Stewartâ€™s favor, awarding him $14,000 in damages.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œExercise of [a] trial judgeâ€™s discretion [as to admission or exclusion of evidence] will not be disturbed on appeal absent [a] clear showing of abuse of discretion, the commission of legal error, and prejudice to rights of appellant.â€Â  Bonaparte v. Floyd, 291 S.C. 427, 437, 354 S.E.2d 40, 47 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  â€œOn appeal of a case tried by a jury, the jurisdiction of this court extends merely to the correction of errors of law, and a factual finding of the jury will not be disturbed unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence which reasonably supports the juryâ€™s findings.â€Â  Rogers v. Norfolk S. Corp., 343 S.C. 52, 59, 538 S.E.2d 664, 668 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
DISCUSSION
Stewart claims the trial court erred in allowing Flynnâ€™s counsel to cross examine Mrs. Stewart regarding Mr. Stewartâ€™s Social Security Disability benefits.Â  This allegation is not properly preserved for our review.
â€œUnder the collateral source rule, a tortfeasor has no right to any mitigation of damages because of payments or compensation received by the injured person from an independent source.â€Â  Young v. Warr, 252 S.C. 179, 197, 165 S.E.2d 797, 806 (1969).Â  However, our courts have created a clear exception to the collateral source rule when the admission of such testimony is relevant to the witnessâ€™s credibility.Â  Rhodes v. Spartanburg County, 262 S.C. 644, 207 S.E.2d 85 (1974).Â  
The duty is on the litigant to make a timely objection in order to preserve the right of review.Â  Parks v. Morris Homes Corp., 245 S.C. 461, 141 S.E.2d 129 (1965).Â  â€œFailure to make an objection at the time evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to object.â€Â  Doe v. S.B.M., 327 S.C. 352, 356, 488 S.E.2d 878, 880 (Ct. App. 1997).
In the present case, Flynn argued Mrs. Stewartâ€™s testimony that the family was struggling financially opened the door to cross examination on the Social Security Disability benefits.Â  Flynn intended to introduce the collateral source to show that the Stewarts were not in such bad shape financially and to lessen the emotional impact of Mrs. Stewartâ€™s testimony.Â  At this point in the trial the parties reached a compromise in camera.Â  Stewartâ€™s counsel agreed not to object to cross examination questions about Social Security income so long as the trial court gave a jury charge on the collateral source rule and so long as he was permitted to ask certain questions on redirect examination. 
When trial resumed both parties proceeded according to the compromise.Â  At the trialâ€™s conclusion the judge charged the jury on the collateral source rule.Â  Stewart argues in his brief that contrary to the agreement, the trial judge limited his ability â€œto explore and explain the issues raised by the admission of the collateral source.â€Â  Stewartâ€™s counsel apparently wanted to explore and explain the collateral source of income with testimony from Dr. Charles Alford, a vocational rehabilitation professional.Â  
Upon review of the record on appeal, this court is unable to find any objections made by Stewartâ€™s counsel during either Mrs. Stewartâ€™s or Dr. Alfordâ€™s testimony.Â  Thus, Stewart did not make a contemporaneous objection, as required, to properly preserve the alleged error for appellate review.Â  State v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 386, 440 S.E.2d 869 (1994).Â  
Since we find the admittance of evidence of a collateral source is not preserved for appellate review, we need not address the issue of whether that alleged error affected the juryâ€™s verdict, or whether it required a new trial nisi additur. 
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[2]Â 
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] An x-ray of Stewartâ€™s spine showed an old compression fracture but no new fractures were detected.Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Juan Marin, Appellant,
v.
Black & Decker Distribution, Inc., Employer, and Speciality Risk Services, Carrier,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-241
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 15, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Garth H. White, of Charlotte, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this workersâ€™ compensation action, Juan Marin appeals the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s order denying Marinâ€™s claim for depression as a change of condition.Â  We affirm. 1  
FACTS
Marin filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim against Black & Decker Distribution, Inc., and Speciality Risk Services (collectively â€œBlack & Deckerâ€), asserting he was injured when a roll of plastic fell on his right leg while he was operating a forklift.Â  At the hearing on October 24, 2001, the issues presented to the single commissioner were (1) whether Marin was entitled to temporary total disability from March 2, 2001 to July 30, 2001 and (2) whether his alleged depression was causally related to the admitted injury to the foot. 
During the hearing, Marin testified the injury to his foot rendered him unable to walk, which caused him to be depressed because he was unable to support his family.Â  Marin denied experiencing depression prior to his injury and stated he believed his depression stemmed from his failure to provide for his family.Â  Marin became emotional when he spoke of his daughterâ€™s behavioral problems at school.Â  
The single commissioner held Marin was entitled to temporary total disability only from the date of the accident until March 26, 2001, when he was to return to work with restrictions but failed to do so.Â  She found that if Marin was depressed, the depression was unrelated to the injury and stemmed from his daughterâ€™s difficulties at school.Â  Accordingly, the single commissioner concluded Marinâ€™s claim for depression was not compensable.Â  
On February 15, 2002, Marin filed a motion to admit additional evidence to the commission, seeking to introduce medical records and a letter from his doctor dated January 15, 2002, in which the doctor opined Marinâ€™s depression was related to his pain.Â  The commission denied the motion, finding the evidence sought to be admitted did not meet the criteria of newly discovered evidence, pursuant to South Carolina Regulation 67-707 (Supp. 2005), because it was developed after the hearing.Â  
On appeal, the commission reversed the single commissionerâ€™s denial of temporary total benefits after March 26, 2001 but affirmed the denial of additional benefits related to a claim for depression.Â  Black & Decker appealed the commissionâ€™s ruling on two issues unrelated to this appeal, and the circuit court affirmed the commission.Â  Marin did not appeal the commissionâ€™s decision finding his depression not compensable.
On August 20, 2002, Marin filed a request for a hearing seeking benefits for depression as a change of condition.Â  At the hearing before the single commissioner, Marin testified since the injury to his foot, he suffered from depression, and because his physical ailments have worsened, he contemplated suicide.Â  The single commissioner denied Marinâ€™s claim for depression as a change of condition, finding Marin had previously requested a hearing as to the compensability of his depression and because Marin had not appealed the decision finding his depression not compensable, that ruling was the law of the case.Â  Additionally, the single commissioner found the change of condition statute does not allow a claimant to maintain a change of condition claim for an injury that was previously considered and not compensated.Â  Further, the single commissioner found the doctrine of res judicata barred Marinâ€™s claim.Â  
The Appellate Panel of the Workerâ€™s Compensation Commission affirmed the single commissioner, adopting the single commissionerâ€™s findings in full.Â  The circuit court found the decision of the commission was supported by substantial evidence in the record and affirmed that decision.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  This court can reverse or modify the commissionâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the [commission] reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  
The determination of whether a claimant experiences a change of condition is a question for the fact finder.Â  Krell v. S.C. State Hwy. Dept., 237 S.C. 584, 588, 118 S.E.2d 322, 323-24 (1961).Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.       Change of Condition
Marin argues his claim for depression was not barred by the doctrine of res judicata but rather was compensable as a change of condition.Â  We disagree.Â  
Under the doctrine of res judicata, a litigant is barred from raising issues previously adjudicated between the parties in a subsequent action.Â  Hilton Head Ctr. of S.C., Inc. v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n of S.C., 294 S.C. 9, 11, 362 S.E.2d 176, 177 (1987).Â  Res judicata requires three elements:Â  (1) a judgment that is final, valid, and on the merits; (2) the parties in the second action are identical to those in the first; and (3) the subsequent action must involve a subject matter properly included in the first action.Â  See Owenby v. Owens Corning Fiberglas, 313 S.C. 181, 183, 437 S.E.2d 130, 131 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
However, our workersâ€™ compensation statute allows for consideration of a change of condition.Â  South Carolina Code section 42-17-90 (1985) provides:

Upon its own motion or upon the application of any party in interest on the ground of a change in condition, the Commission may review any award and on such review may make an award ending, diminishing or increasing the compensation previously awarded, subject to the maximum or minimum provided in this Title, and shall immediately send to the parties a copy of the order changing the award.Â  No such review shall affect such award as regards any moneys paid and no such review shall be made after twelve months from the date of the last payment of compensation pursuant to an award under this Title.

This section is â€œlimited to the consideration of a change in condition of the injury on which the original award was made.â€Â  Estridge v. Joslyn Clark Controls, Inc., 325 S.C. 532, 537, 482 S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  A change in condition occurs when a claimant undergoes a change in condition as a result of the original injury, occurring after the first award has been made.Â  Causby v. Rock Hill Printing & Finishing Co., 249 S.C. 225, 227, 153 S.E. 2d 697, 698 (1967).Â  To be compensable, a mental condition must be induced by a compensable physical injury or by unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment.Â  Getsinger v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas, 335 S.C. 77, 80, 515 S.E.2d 104, 106 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In order to establish a modification based on a change of condition, the claimant must show a change of condition, and the change must be based upon a causal connection to the original compensable accident.Â  Krell v. S.C. State Highway Depâ€™t, 237 S.C. 584, 588, 118 S.E.2d 322, 323 (1961) (citations omitted).Â  Seeking review as a change of condition â€œis not available as an alternative to, or substitute for, an appeal.â€Â  Gattis v. Murrells Inlet VFW # 10420, 353 S.C. 100, 109, 576 S.E.2d 191, 195 (Ct. App. 2003). 
We agree with the circuit court that Owenby v. Owens Corning Fiberglas, 313 S.C. 181, 437 S.E.2d 130 (Ct. App. 1993), is applicable to the present case.Â  In Owenby, the claimant suffered a work-related injury when a piece of glass became embedded in her finger.Â  The finger became infected and had to be partially amputated.Â  The circuit court and Full Commission affirmed the Single Commissionerâ€™s denial of benefits for psychological injury.Â  The claimant did not appeal.Â  Subsequently, the claimant filed a change of condition form based upon the full amputation of her finger and the worsening of her psychological condition.Â  This court, finding that res judicata barred the claimantâ€™s claim, stated:

All three elements are present in the case at hand.Â  In the first action, the trial court affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s finding that any psychological problems suffered by Owenby did not result from her injury and were not compensable.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order was not appealed and, therefore, became a final, valid judgment on the merits.Â  The parties are identical to those in the first action and the issue is the same.Â  Moreover, there is ample evidence on the record that any psychological problems currently suffered by Owenby are a continuation of her previously existing condition which was ruled upon in the initial action.

Id. at 183, 437 S.E.2d at 131-32.Â  
In the present case, the single commissioner in the initial claim found Marinâ€™s claim for depression not compensable.Â  Additionally, the single commissioner found if Marin was indeed depressed, his depression was not causally related to his injury.Â  Rather, the depression stemmed from his daughterâ€™s behavioral problems at school.Â  The commission affirmed the ruling.Â  Because Marin did not appeal from the full commissionâ€™s order denying benefits for his depression, that ruling became a final, valid judgment on the merits.Â  It is undisputed the parties are the same in both actions.Â  Further, Marinâ€™s claim for depression was fully litigated and decided in the first action.Â  Marinâ€™s claim for depression was raised, ruled upon, and not appealed.Â  
Marin relies on Brayboy v. Clark Heating Co., 306 S.C. 56, 59 n.2, 409 S.E.2d 767, 769 n.2 (1991), for the proposition that a claim for a change of condition may be based upon undiagnosed conditions, resulting from the original injury, which are discovered after the first award.Â  Marin argues because the depression was undiagnosed by medical providers until after the first hearing, his claim falls within the type of claim contemplated by Brayboy.Â  Although it is true a change of condition may be based upon undiagnosed conditions that arise subsequent to the hearing, in this case the depression now asserted as a changed condition existed when the commission entered its May 14, 2002 order.Â  Marin cannot now assert he was unaware of his condition because it was not formally diagnosed when he specifically sought benefits for his depression claim at the first hearing.Â  Marin repeatedly testified at the first hearing he believed his depression stemmed from his work-related injury.Â  As stated in the order of the single commissioner adopted in full by the commission, â€œIt is noted that the evidence submitted by claimant from Dr. Patterson in addition to claimantâ€™s own testimony at the first hearing reveals that claimant has complained of depressive symptoms throughout the pendency of this claim.â€Â  
Marin asserts his claim is consistent with Gattis.Â  In Gattis, the claimant filed a Form 50 seeking additional treatments from his doctor.Â  After a hearing held August 19, 1998, the single commissioner found the claimant had not reached MMI and ordered the employer to pay for the treatment.Â  At the hearing before the commission, the claimant sought to introduce a letter from the doctor dated August 18, 1998.Â  The commission refused to allow the admission of the letter, noting that the letter would provide the claimaint with â€œthe opportunity for a change of condition request.â€Â  The commission held the claimant had reached MMI and denied additional treatments.Â  No appeal was taken from this order.Â  The claimant soon thereafter filed a claim for a change of condition.
The commission affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s holding that a change of condition had occurred effective August 18, 1998.Â  The circuit court affirmed this ruling.Â  This court also affirmed.Â  We held, â€œBecause the commission limited its order to a determination of Claimantâ€™s condition prior to August of 1998, subsequent events, including Dr. Hortonâ€™s changed diagnosis in August of 1998, were appropriate for consideration in an action alleging a change of condition.â€Â  Id. at 109, 576 S.E.2d at 195-96.Â  We find Gattis inapplicable to Marinâ€™s case.
In the initial action in the present case, the commission did not place a limit on a timeframe in its consideration of Marinâ€™s condition.Â  As stated above, it fully considered Marinâ€™s claim that his depression was compensable and rejected this claim.
Finally, Marin asserts he is entitled to continuing medical treatment for his depression under Dodge v. Bruccoli, Clark, Layman, Inc., 334 S.C. 574, 514 S.E.2d 593 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In Dodge, this court held that the commission may require additional medical care and treatment even if the claimaint had reached maximum medical improved if such treatment would tend to lessen the period of disability.Â  Id.Â  at 581, 514 S.E.2d at 597.Â  The injury for which the claimant in Dodge sought additional treatment was work-related.Â  In the present case, the commission determined in the initial action that Marinâ€™s depression was not work-related and as stated above, any claim for depression is now barred by res judicata.Â  Therefore, Dodge is clearly inapplicable to the present case.Â  
CONCLUSION
Thus, we find the commissionâ€™s determination that Marinâ€™s depression is not compensable as a change of condition is supported by substantial evidence.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the order of the circuit court affirming the commissionâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Terry Maness, Appellant,
v.
George Ginotoli, Director South Carolina Department of Mental Health, and State of South Carolina, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-242
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 15, 2006Â Â Â 

DISMISSED


  
    
      
Terry Maness, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Elizabeth McMahon, Assistant Attorney General Daniel E. Grigg, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, and George Ginotoli, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Terry Maness appeals a letter indicating he must file his petition for writ of certiorari in federal court.Â  We dismiss for lack of jurisdiction.
FACTS
On February 29, 1985, an Anderson County Grand Jury indicted Maness for two counts of second degree criminal sexual assault on a minor.Â  A jury pronounced Maness guilty of these charges.Â  The trial court sentenced him to twenty years on each count, to be served consecutively.Â  The Supreme Court of South Carolina dismissed his appeal.Â  See State v. Terry Wayne Maness, Op. No. 86-MO-101 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 5, 1986).Â  Maness filed two subsequent applications for post-conviction relief, both of which were dismissed.Â  Furthermore, Maness filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus in the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of South Carolina, which was also dismissed.Â  
On January 5, 2005, Maness sent a second application for a writ of habeas corpus to the Clerk of Court for Anderson County (the Clerk).Â  This application raised the same issues as those alleged in his prior application to the Supreme Court of South Carolina.Â  The Clerk returned this application with a note stating: â€œThere is still a filing fee of $150.00, or you can fill this [motion to proceed in forma pauperis] out and see if the judge will O.K. it.Â  *Shouldnâ€™t this be in FED. CT.?â€Â  According to Maness, he resubmitted his application with the Clerk.Â Â Â  On March 15, 2005, a letter from the office of Judge J. Cordell Maddox indicated that â€œupon review, Judge Maddox determined that this action should be in federal court, not state court.Â  Therefore, [we are] returning these documents to you for proper filing.â€Â  The signature line on this letter is typed and reads: â€œSincerely, Law Clerk.â€Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Maness argues the circuit court erred in determining his action should be filed in federal court and not state court.Â  Because we lack jurisdiction to hear this appeal, we dismiss.
Section 14-8-200(a) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides that this court â€œshall have jurisdiction over any case in which an appeal is taken from an order, judgment, or decree of the circuit or family court.â€Â  In this case, the circuit court has not entered an order, judgment, or decree.Â  However, in the event the letter may be interpreted as a pronouncement from the circuit court, we would still dismiss because it was not entered.Â  See Rule 58(a), SCRCP (â€œA judgment is effective only when . . . entered in the record.â€); First Union Natâ€™l Bank v. Hitman, Inc., 306 S.C. 327, 329, 411 S.E.2d 681, 682 (Ct. App. 1991) (â€œNo order is final until it is written and entered.â€), affâ€™d, 308 S.C. 421, 418 S.E.2d 545 (1992); see also Case v. Case, 243 S.C. 447, 134 S.E.2d 394 (1964) (judgments in general are not final until written and entered).Â  Accordingly, this appeal is
 DISMISSED.  [1]
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: SunTrust Mortgage v. Gobbi
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
SunTrust Mortgage f/k/a Crestar Mortgage Corporation,
Respondent,
v.
Scott Gobbi a/k/a Arthur Scott Gobbi, Jara Uzenda Gobbi a/k/a Jara Carlow
Uzenda, Lyonâ€™s Cove Horizontal Property Regime, Paul Himmelsbach, Defendants,
of whom Scott Gobbi a/k/a Arthur Scott Gobbi, Lyonâ€™s Cove Horizontal Property Regime, and Paul Himmelsbach are
Respondents
and Jara Uzenda Gobbi is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-243
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 16, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jara Uzenda Gobbi, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Brian C. Gambrell and John Sanford Kay, both of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jara Uzenda Gobbi appeals the trial judgeâ€™s decision to deny her in forma pauperis status.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Gobbi and her ex-husband, Scott Gobbi, had numerous properties in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, that went into foreclosure.Â  Several foreclosure actions were filed against Gobbi, and she removed them to federal court.Â  Gobbi also filed several civil actions in state court against the various lien holders.Â  In civil action number 2002-CP-26-3044, Gobbi sued SunTrust Mortgage and various other lien holders.Â  On December 4, 2002, Judge Baxley dismissed the action, finding the action was â€œvexacious to the Defendantsâ€ and noting that the case was â€œsuccessive, repetitive, and involve[d] matters which are res judicata as to all of the Defendants.â€Â  Judge Baxley ordered that Gobbi was prohibited from filing â€œany new or additional lawsuits, motions, writs, or any documents requesting any relief of any sort . . . arising from the same core set of facts and circumstances involved in this case, upon penalty of contempt . . . .â€Â  
In the underlying matter, the Bank of New York sought to foreclose on one of Gobbiâ€™s properties in case number 02-CP-26-3774.[2]Â  Thereafter, the claim was transferred to SunTrust Mortgage.Â  At some point in time, SunTrustâ€™s original attorney was relieved.Â  Gobbi filed several motions, including a motion to compel the answers of her co-defendants; a motion to dismiss; a motion to proceed in forma pauperis and exempt service on non-answering defendants; and a motion to compel the grounds for relieving SunTrustâ€™s former attorney.Â Â  
On January 5, 2004, hearings were held before Judge Cottingham on thirty-eight motions in numerous suits involving Gobbi.Â  After the hearing on the motions in case number 02-CP-26-3774, Judge Cottingham orally granted Gobbiâ€™s motion to proceed in forma pauperis; granted her request not to serve the non-answering defendants; and denied the remaining motions.Â  A form order was issued to that effect that same day.Â  On January 8, 2004, Judge Cottingham sua sponte reconsidered his ruling on the in forma pauperis status.Â  Judge Cottingham issued another form order stating: â€œAfter review I have concluded my order of Jan 5, 2004 allowing the defendant Jara Gobbi to proceed in forma pauperis was improvidently granted, and that motion is hereby denied.â€Â  Judge Cottingham denied Gobbiâ€™s motion for reconsideration in a formal order, noting that he reversed his decision on the in forma pauperis status â€œafter reflection and review of the voluminous record involving the litigation involving Defendant Jara Gobbi.â€Â  He held that requiring Gobbi to pay the filing fee would act as a deterrent to abusive and frivolous filings.Â  Judge Cottingham further found that Gobbi had previously been â€œsanctioned for abusive and frivolous filings on two prior occasions by Judge Baxley, and [had] been threatened with sanctions by the Honorable Cameron M. Currie.Â  In light of her prior history of litigation and discovery abuse, Defendant Jara Gobbiâ€™s request for leave to proceed informa pauperis is again DENIED.â€Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction
Gobbi argues Judge Cottingham lacked jurisdiction in the underlying matter and the order denying in forma pauperis status was void.Â  She asserts Judge Baxley previously ruled on the matters, Judge Baxleyâ€™s prior order was res judicata, and Judge Baxley should have been the judge to rule on her motions.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we address whether the judge had jurisdiction to sua sponte change the order regarding the in forma pauperis status.Â  â€œUnder Rule 59(e), SCRCP, the trial judge has only ten days from entry of judgment to alter or amend an earlier order on his own initiative absent a â€˜reservationâ€™ of jurisdiction in the form order.â€Â  Leviner v. Sonoco Prod. Co., 339 S.C. 492, 494, 530 S.E.2d 127, 128 (2000).Â  Judge Cottingham sua sponte reversed his order granting Gobbi in forma pauperis status three days after its issuance.Â  This is within ten days of entry of judgment.Â  Thus, Judge Cottingham had the jurisdiction to change the order on his own initiative.Â  Id.Â  
We now turn to Gobbiâ€™s allegation that Judge Baxley, not Judge Cottingham, had jurisdiction over the underlying matter.[3]Â  
The South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provide a mechanism for replacing a judge when he or she is unable to continue in a case:

If by reason of death, sickness, or other disability, a judge before whom an action has been tried is unable to perform the duties to be performed by the court under these rules after a verdict is returned or findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed, then the resident judge of the circuit or any other judge having jurisdiction in the court in which the action was tried may perform those duties; but if such other judge is satisfied that he cannot perform those duties because he did not preside at the trial or for any other reason, he may in his discretion grant a new trial.

Rule 63, SCRCP.[4]Â  
At the January 5, 2004 motions hearing in the underlying action, Gobbi argued civil action number 2002-CP-26-3774 should be dismissed because Judge Baxleyâ€™s prior order held that all of the issues concerning foreclosure had been decided and that no further actions should be filed under penalty of contempt.Â  After Judge Cottingham denied her motions, she moved for reconsideration, requesting a ruling as to whether jurisdiction was with Judge Baxley or with Judge Cottingham.Â Â  
Gobbi argued at the hearing on the motion for reconsideration that Judge Baxley still had jurisdiction over the matter.Â  In his March 4, 2004 order, Judge Cottingham ruled that Judge Baxley was â€œdisabledâ€ for the purposes of Rule 63, SCRCP, because he was no longer assigned to that judicial circuit:

At the hearing, the issue was raised of whether Judge Baxley, a Circuit Court judge temporarily assigned to Horry County from another judicial circuit is â€œdisabledâ€ pursuant to Rule 63, SCRCP.Â  At the hearing, I ruled that because Judge Baxley is no longer assigned to this judicial circuit, he was â€œdisabledâ€ pursuant to Rule 63, SCRCP.Â  Therefore the Chief Administrative Judge of the Fifteenth Judicial Circuit took the appropriate step to reassign this case to me to make all necessary determinations in this case.Â  Upon further review, my ruling was appropriate in light of Ness v. Eckerd Corp., 350 S.C. 399, 566 S.E.2d 193 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  

Gobbi asserts Judge Cottingham erred in his ruling because Judge Baxley was not sick, deceased, or otherwise disabled merely because he was out of the circuit.Â  However, we agree with Judge Cottingham that Judge Baxley was no longer assigned to the circuit.Â  Nothing in the record indicates that Judge Cottingham could not become familiar with the case.Â  There is no evidence in the record that Judge Baxley was the only judge assigned to Gobbiâ€™s numerous civil actions.Â  Further, judicial ecomony was served when Judge Cottingham was assigned as the judge to hear all thirty-eight motions on January 5, 2004.Â  Because the intent of Rule 63 is to allow a smooth transition from a judge who is unable to complete a case to a judge who can complete the case, we find no error with Judge Cottinghamâ€™s ruling.Â  Accordingly, Judge Cottingham properly exercised his jurisdiction to rule on Gobbiâ€™s motions.Â  
II.Â  Entitlement to In Forma Pauperis Status
Gobbi argues Judge Cottingham erred in denying her in forma pauperis status because SunTrust did not object to the status.Â  Therefore, Gobbi argues, Judge Cottinghamâ€™s decision was without evidentiary support and was arbitrary and baseless.Â  We find no error.
Generally, a plaintiff seeking to file an action in forma pauperis files a motion to proceed under that status along with the proposed complaint and an affidavit of indigency.Â  Rule 3(c), SCRCP.Â  However, a judge may deny a party in forma pauperis status to prevent fraud and abuse.Â  See In re Maxton, 325 S.C. 3, 5, 478 S.E.2d 679, 679 (1996) (denying an inmate in forma pauperis status and threatening him with sanctions where inmate had frivolously filed sixty-four motions concerning the same or related matters).Â  The decision to deny a party in forma pauperis status will not be reversed where there are specific findings that a partyâ€™s repetitive filings are frivolous and abusive.Â  See Lakes v. State, 333 S.C. 382, 386, 510 S.E.2d 228, 230-31 (Ct. App. 1999) (reversing a judgeâ€™s denial of in forma pauperis status in a post-conviction relief action where the order failed to include factual findings that the inmateâ€™s numerous filings rose to the level of the repetitive and abusive filings in Maxton). 
In her motion to proceed in forma pauperis, Gobbi alleged she was financially devastated by the more than twenty-four actions she was involved in.Â  Gobbi did not present any other evidence to support her allegation that she was indigent.Â  Evidence in the record did show, however, that Gobbi was threatened with sanctions for frivolous filings on prior occasions.Â  Judge Baxley ruled on matters in at least ten civil actions involving the same core facts and circumstances.Â  Noting that Gobbi filed additional, repetitive, non-meritorious motions in the cases after the actions were ended, Judge Baxley prohibited her from filing any new lawsuits, motions, writs or any other documents seeking relief arising from the same core set of facts upon penalty of contempt.Â  Judge Cameron M. Currie remanded to state court Gobbiâ€™s removal of eight foreclosure actions to federal court and dismissed her initiation of one action against various attorneys and SunTrust in federal court.Â  In denying Gobbiâ€™s motion for reconsideration, Judge Currie advised Gobbi that if she persisted in filing motions in the litigation, the court could determine the motions to be frivolous and impose sanctions pursuant to Rule 11(c), Fed. R. Civ. P.Â Â Â Â Â  
Judge Cottinghamâ€™s order in the present case denying in forma pauperis status to Gobbi is supported by the record.Â  Judge Cottingham made a specific finding that Gobbi filed numerous, frivolous lawsuits concerning the same matters.Â  Judge Baxley and Judge Currie also warned Gobbi that her numerous filings were frivolous and could warrant sanctions.Â  Because Judge 
  Cottingham made specific findings that Gobbiâ€™s numerous filings were frivolous and amounted to litigation abuse, we find no error with the decision to deny in forma pauperis status.Â  
CONCLUSION
Judge Cottingham had proper jurisdiction to determine the issues before him.Â  Further, Judge Cottinghamâ€™s order denying Gobbi in forma pauperis status is supported by the record.Â  Accordingly, the order of Judge Cottingham is 
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The lien holder also sought to foreclose on another of Gobbiâ€™s properties in civil action number 02-CP-26-2639.Â  Gobbi originally appealed the lower courtâ€™s decision on her motions in that case number as well.Â  By order dated December 13, 2004, this court determined that Gobbiâ€™s appeal of all of the issues in civil action number 02-CP-26-2639 was interlocutory.Â  Thus, the only issue remaining on appeal for us to determine is whether the trial judge erred in denying Gobbiâ€™s motion to file in forma pauperis in civil action number 02-CP-26-3774.Â  
[3]Â  We note Gobbi did not raise her argument that Judge Baxley was the appropriate judge to hear the matter until her motion for reconsideration.Â  Generally, this would render the matter unpreserved for appellate review.Â  See Eaddy v. Oliver, 345 S.C. 39, 44, 545 S.E.2d 830, 833(Ct. App. 2001) (holding that a party cannot use a motion for reconsideration to present an issue that could have been raised prior to the judgment but was not).Â  Nothing in Rule 63, SCRCP indicates substitution of a judge raises concerns about the subject matter jurisdiction of the court.Â  See Watson v. Watson, 319 S.C. 92, 93, 460 S.E.2d 394, 395 (1995) (noting that subject matter jurisdiction refers to the courtâ€™s power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong).Â  However, Gobbi has couched her issue in terms of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Thus, we will review this matter.Â  Hallums v. Bowens, 318 S.C. 1, 3, 428 S.E.2d 894, 895 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding that issues of subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time).Â Â Â  
[4] Â Rule 63 was amended by order dated April 28, 2004.Â  This amendment took effect after the hearing in this matter.Â  Therefore, we cite to the earlier version of the rule.
