THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Darrel Jackson, Appellant.
      
    
  

Â Â Â  

Appeal from Spartanburg County
J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-244
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 16, 2006

 AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Theo W. Mitchell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Appellant Darrel Jackson appeals his conviction of animal cruelty to twelve pit bull dogs.Â  The conviction forfeited his right to custody and ownership of his pit bulls pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. section 47-1-170 (Supp. 2005).Â  According to section 47-1-150(F), the Humane Society was empowered to make â€œhumane dispositionâ€ of all Jacksonâ€™s vicious and dangerous pit bulls.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 47-1-150(F) (Supp. 2005).Â  We affirm.[1]
Facts
On October 13, 2003, Elizabeth Tilley, an employee of the City of Spartanburg Animal Control, went to 433 Farley Avenue to investigate a claim regarding thirty-one pit bulls.Â  When Tilley arrived, she located only twenty-one pit bulls.Â  She described the dogs as looking very thin with â€œbig, heavy chains.â€ Â Because Tilley could clearly see their rib cages and several of the dogs had â€œswollen stomachs,â€ she called a Spartanburg City Public Safety Officer.Â  Once the officer arrived, Tilley and the officer photographed the dogs in the backyard.Â  Several dogs were chained closely to their doghouses, surrounded by feces and trash.Â  Jacksonâ€™s mother owned the house.Â  Jackson admitted the pit bulls belonged to him.
Based on the evidence, Tilley was granted a search warrant, which she executed on October 14 at 433 Farley Avenue.Â  At that time, Tilley and several other officers seized the dogs and the chains.Â  The chains were so heavy and cumbersome that Tilley and the officers were forced to contact the Spartanburg Public Safety Fire Department in order to use their bolt cutters.
Dr. Jean Stewart Hovis, DVM, examined the pit bulls upon their arrival at the Humane Society.Â  Dr. Hovis opined that all of the dogs were moderately to severely underweight and many had multiple bite marks.Â  Furthermore, their chains were extremely heavy and proportionally excessive to individual body mass. Â Many of the chains weighed more than half of the dogâ€™s own weight.
Jackson was charged with the ill treatment of twenty-one pit bull dogs.Â  He was tried in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  The jury found Jackson guilty on twelve counts and not guilty on nine counts.Â  Two counts were dismissed because two dogs died prior to the trial.Â  He was sentenced to ninety days in jail or a fine of $7,575.
Jackson appealed to the circuit judge, who upheld his convictions and sentences.Â  An order granting custody to the Humane Society for humane disposition of the remaining dogs was affirmed.Â  Jackson appeals the forfeiture of the ten living pit bulls and the Humane Societyâ€™s custody for purposes of a humane disposition.Â  He does not challenge his conviction or any other aspect of the sentence.
Standard of Review
In criminal appeals from magistrate or municipal court, the circuit court does not conduct a de novo review, but instead reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate exception. Â State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Henderson, 347 S.C. 455, 556 S.E.2d 691 (Ct. App. 2001). Â The appellate court reviewing the criminal appeal from the circuit court may review for errors of law only. Â State v. Cutter, 261 S.C. 140, 199 S.E.2d 61 (1973); Henderson, 347 S.C. at 457, 556 S.E.2d at 692. Â In criminal cases, the court of appeals sits to review errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous. Â State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 625 S.E.2d 239 (Ct. App. 2006); Landis, 362 S.C. at 101, 606 S.E.2d at 505.
Discussion

I. Â The Order

An argument not raised to and ruled upon by the trial court is not preserved for review.Â  See State v. Simmons, 360 S.C. 33, 599 S.E.2d 448 (2004) (noting that, to be preserved for appellate review, issue must be raised and ruled upon in the trial court).Â  The appellant has â€œthe responsibility to identify errors on appeal, not the court.â€ Â Kennedy v. South Carolina Ret. Sys., 349 S.C. 531, 532-33, 564 S.E.2d 322, 322-23 (2001).Â  â€œThis court has consistently refused to apply the plain error rule.â€ Â Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 306, 486 S.E. 2d 750, 759 (1997).Â  â€œAn issue that was not preserved for review should not be addressed by the Court of Appeals.â€ Â State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693-94 (2003).
In the case sub judice, no objection was raised in magistrateâ€™s court that seizure of the abused animals was improper on statutory or constitutional grounds.Â  During his sentencing, Jackson failed to move to alter or amend the order that contemplated the destruction of the dogs by the Humane Society. No objection was made challenging the Humane Societyâ€™s command over the dogs.Â  Even if the issue were preserved, it would be meritless.
South Carolina Code Annotated section 47-1-170 states: â€œThe owner or person having charge or custody of an animal cruelly used who is convicted of any violation of this chapter forfeits ownership, charge, or custody of the animal.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 47-1-170 (Supp. 2005). Â Section 47-1-150(F)(2) provides: â€œThe officer or agent of any county or of the South Carolina Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, or of any society incorporated for that purpose, taking charge of an animal as provided for in this section shall provide for the animal until . . . [t]he animal is turned over to the officer or agent as provided in Section 47-1-170 and a humane disposition of the animal is made.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 47-1-150(F)(2) (Supp. 2005).
Jackson disputes the Humane Societyâ€™s authority to take custody of and dispose of the animals but fails to cite authority requiring the magistrateâ€™s order to make findings of fact regarding the forfeiture in section 47-1-170.

II. Â SubstantialÂ  Evidence

Jackson argues that no evidence supports the forfeiture and destruction of his pit bulls. Â The testimony of Tilley and Dr. Hovis, along with the pictures of the dogs, were sufficient for a jury to convict.Â  There is substantial evidence to support his convictions.

III. Â Abuse of Discretion

Jackson contends the magistrateâ€™s court abused its discretion.Â  Citing Chemical Leaman Tank Lines, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 258 S.C 518, 189 S.E.2d 296 (1972), Jackson argues the forfeiture is arbitrary and capricious as a matter of law.Â  Chemical Leaman Tank Lines is inapplicable because it merely states the scope of review of an action by the Public Service Commission is an administrative law action.Â  Id.Â  In addition, Jackson cites State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 543 S.E.2d 286 (Ct. App. 2001), overruled by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005).Â  Jackson did not articulate his purpose for citing Hamilton.
Jacksonâ€™s reliance on State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 613 S.E.2d 381 (Ct. App. 2005), is misplaced.Â  Preslar addressed the admissibility of a pending charge of criminal sexual conduct with a minor in a trial for the charge of intimidation of a witness where the witness was the victim of the criminal sexual conduct.Â  Id.Â  The charge was found admissible under res gestae.Â  Jacksonâ€™s reasoning is wholly without merit or logic.

IV. Â Constitutional Issue

Jackson asserts the phrase â€œtake whatever steps it deems proper to dispose of the dogsâ€ is unconstitutional, broad, vague, arbitrary and capricious.
A constitutional argument is not preserved for appeal where appellant failed to argue the constitutional basis for his request at trial.Â  State v. Byram, 326 S.C 107, 112-113, 485 S.E.2d 360, 362-63 (1997).Â  Moreover, one to whose conduct the law clearly applies does not have standing to challenge on constitutional vagueness. Â State v. Michau, 355 S.C. 73, 583 S.E.2d 756 (2003).Â  The evidentiary record revealed the dogs were subject to animal cruelty.Â  Likewise, the evidence shows that Jackson was unfit to care for the pit bulls.Â  Even Jackson averred that â€œthem dogs are real aggressive.â€
Because Jacksonâ€™s arguments on the constitutionality of the statute are conclusory, the issue should be deemed abandoned on appeal.Â  See State v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 518 S.E.2d 278 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating conclusory argument in brief constitutes abandonment of issue on appeal).

V. Â Custody

Jackson argues the dogsâ€™ custody and destruction by the Humane Society contradicts the purpose of the animal cruelty act.Â  This assertion is
meritless.
Other than stating in his brief that the animals were illegally seized, Jackson made no objection at trial.Â  The purpose of the statute is to prevent acts of cruelty including: malnourishment, lack of proper medical care, lack of shelter, overloading with heavy chains, and allowing the dogs to inflict injuries upon each other.
The humane destruction of animals unfit for adoption is not animal cruelty as defined by the statute but an appropriate use of police power to protect the public. Â Sentell v. New Orleans & Carrollton RR. Co., 166 U.S. 698 (1897) (finding legislators may permit the destruction of dogs for safety and protection of citizens). Â Section 47-1-170 clarifies that humane disposition is done to prevent further animal cruelty and to protect society from dangerous animals.
Conclusion
Accordingly, Jacksonâ€™s convictions and sentences are
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jara Uzenda Gobbi, Appellant,
v.
Peopleâ€™s Federal Bank, Richard M. Lovelace, Jr., and Lynette R.
Hedgepath, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-245
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 16, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jara Uzenda Gobbi, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Elizabeth S. Gordon, of Charleston, Lynette Rogers Hedgepath and Richard M. Lovelace, Jr., both of Conway; for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action arising out of the transfer of a deed and subsequent procurement of a mortgage, Jara Uzenda Gobbi appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order dismissing all of her causes of action.Â  Gobbi argues the court erred in:Â  (1) finding it had jurisdiction to hear the motions in the case; (2) declining to grant her motion to enlarge the time to file a motion to reconsider; (3) failing to give proper notice of the hearing; and (4) finding she had to comply with previously-issued circuit court orders despite the existence of outstanding motions.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On June 26, 2002, Gobbi commenced this action against Peopleâ€™s Federal Bank, and attorneys Richard M. Lovelace, Jr. and Lynette R. Hedgepath (Respondents).Â  In her complaint, Gobbi contended Lovelace â€œcoerced and trickedâ€ her into converting a Myrtle Beach lot, which was designated as a business asset, to a marital asset. Â She alleged that Lovelace, who proceeded to represent her husband in a divorce action, persuaded her to deed the property so that it would become subject to equitable division in family court.Â  Additionally, Gobbi asserted the law firm of Lovelace and Hedgepath issued defective title insurance on the deed.Â  Finally, Gobbi claimed Peopleâ€™s Federal Bank improperly executed a mortgage on the property.Â  Based on these allegations, Gobbi sought a declaratory judgment and raised the following causes of action concerning Lovelace:Â  (1) fraudulent conveyance; (2) negligent misrepresentation; (3) breach of contract; and (4) breach of trust.Â  As to the law firm of Lovelace and Hedgepath, Gobbi claimed legal malpractice.Â  Gobbi also asserted a cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty against Peopleâ€™s Federal Bank.Â  As to all defendants, Gobbi claimed:Â  (1) civil conspiracy; (2) fraud; and (3) intentional infliction of emotional and financial harm. 
In response, Lovelace generally denied the allegations and raised the following affirmative defenses:Â  (1) the three-year statute of limitations; (2) res judicata; and (3) the South Carolina Frivolous Proceedings Act.Â  Lovelace also sought a temporary injunction prohibiting Gobbi from filing any other actions or motions in Horry County until after her current action was resolved.Â  In conjunction, Lovelace filed motions to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, the three-year statute of limitations, and res judicata.Â  Lovelace also moved pursuant to Rule 12(e), SCRCP for Gobbi to make a more definite statement of her causes of action. 
Similarly, Hedgepath generally denied Gobbiâ€™s allegations and raised the following affirmative defenses:Â  (1) failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP; (2) failure to plead the specific elements of fraud as required by Rule 9(b), SCRCP; (3) the three-year statute of limitations; (4) abuse of process; and (5) the South Carolina Frivolous Proceedings Act.Â Â  Hedgepath also sought a temporary injunction against Gobbi.Â  On the same date that Hedgepath filed her answer and counterclaim, she filed motions to dismiss which were identical in substance to Lovelaceâ€™s motions.
Peopleâ€™s Federal Bank also generally denied Gobbiâ€™s allegations and asserted Gobbiâ€™s complaint should be dismissed for the following reasons:Â  (1) inadequate service of process; (2) failure to state facts sufficient to state a cause of action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6); (3) collateral estoppel; (4) the three-year statute of limitations; (5) failure to plead the requisite elements of fraud; and (6) failure to plead special damages as required for a cause of action for conspiracy. 
When conflict arose between the parties regarding discovery issues, the case was set for a hearing on September 18, 2002, before Circuit Court Judge James E. Lockemy.Â  On the day of the hearing, Judge Lockemy issued a form order in which he ordered Gobbi to be available for Lovelace to depose her within thirty days from the date of the order.Â  Judge Lockemy also discussed with the parties about scheduling another hearing to rule on the partiesâ€™ pending motions. 
On February 14, 2003, Judge Lockemy held a hearing on the partiesâ€™ outstanding motions.Â  At the conclusion of the hearing, Judge Lockemy orally ruled and issued a form order in which he took under advisement Lovelaceâ€™s motion to dismiss for res judicata.Â  He struck Gobbiâ€™s causes of action for breach of trust, intentional infliction of emotional and financial harm, and financial harm.Â  As to Gobbiâ€™s remaining causes of action, Judge Lockemy ordered Gobbi to:Â  (1) fully answer Peopleâ€™s Federal Bankâ€™s request to produce within fourteen days; (2) obtain within forty-five days an affidavit from an attorney establishing the standard of care for legal malpractice and outlining how Lovelace and Hedgepath deviated from this standard; (3) make more definite and certain her claim for fraud and to state with specificity her damage claims for all causes of actions; and (4) to appear at a scheduled deposition and bring all of her documents supporting her claims against Respondents. Â Â Additionally, Judge Lockemy instructed the parties that Gobbiâ€™s lawsuit would be treated as a cause of action for damages as opposed to declaratory judgment action requested by Gobbi.
Because Gobbi failed to comply with the mandates of the February 14, 2003 order, Judge Lockemy issued an order on April 14, 2003, in which he struck Gobbiâ€™s causes of action for legal malpractice and fraud.Â  He also granted Gobbi an additional thirty days to definitively state her claims for damages.Â  Finally, Judge Lockemy informed the parties that he would no longer be presiding over the case because he had been called to report for active military duty on April 21, 2003.Â  He requested the pending motions to dismiss be placed on the motions calendar and reassigned to another judge by the Chief Administrative Judge. 
On May 9, 2003, Gobbi filed a motion to enlarge the time to file a motion for reconsideration of Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders dated February 14, 2003, and April 14, 2003.Â  Because Judge Lockemy requested that the case be assigned to another judge, Gobbi moved for the two orders to be stayed until another judge was assigned.
Ultimately, the case was assigned to Circuit Court Judge Edward B. Cottingham who held a hearing on January 5, 2004, to resolve the partiesâ€™ outstanding motions.Â  During the hearing, Judge CottinghamÂ  informed the parties that he had been assigned the case as a result of Judge Lockemyâ€™s military service.Â  Specifically, Judge Cottingham found Judge Lockemy was unavailable and, thus, he assumed jurisdiction over the case.Â  After hearing arguments from the parties, Judge Cottingham declined to overrule Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders and found that Gobbi had not complied with these orders. Based on this finding, Judge Cottingham dismissed Gobbiâ€™s remaining causes of action in an order dated January 5, 2004.Â  
On January 28, 2004, Gobbi filed a motion for reconsideration of Judge Cottinghamâ€™s order. Â In her motion, Gobbi raised several issues including a challenge to Judge Cottinghamâ€™s jurisdiction to hear her motion to reconsider Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders.Â  Gobbi also requested a hearing on her motion.Â  
Without holding a hearing, Judge Cottingham ruled on Gobbiâ€™s motion.Â  Â Â By order dated April 6, 2004, Judge Cottingham found upon review of the case file that Gobbi had not filed a motion to reconsider Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders.Â  Instead, Judge Cottingham noted that Gobbi had only filed a motion to enlarge the time to file a motion for reconsideration.Â  Based on this procedural error, Judge Cottingham concluded that Gobbi had not timely filed her motion to reconsider and, thus, Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders dated February 14, 2003, and April 14, 2003, were the law of the case.Â  Because Gobbi had failed to comply with the terms of these orders, Judge Cottingham dismissed Gobbiâ€™s remaining causes of action.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
I.Â  
Gobbi argues Judge Cottinghamâ€™s order should be â€œdeemed void or voidable for lack of jurisdiction.â€ Â Specifically, she contends that Judge Lockemy retained jurisdiction over any motions to reconsider his orders and, thus, Judge Cottingham was without jurisdiction to rule on Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders.Â  We disagree.
Rule 63 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure governs the disposition of this issue.Â  Rule 63 provides:

If by reason of death, sickness, or other disability, a judge before whom an action has been tried is unable to perform the duties to be performed by the court under these rules after a verdict is returned or findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed, then the resident judge of the circuit or any other judge having jurisdiction in the court in which the action was tried may perform those duties; but if such other judge is satisfied that he cannot perform those duties because he did not preside at the trial or for any other reason, he may in his discretion grant a new trial.

Rule 63, SCRCP.[2]
Initially, we note that Gobbi appeared to recognize that Judge Lockemy would be unavailable due to his military duty to rule on any motions after he issued the order dated April 14, 2003.Â  Significantly, in her motion to enlarge the time to file a motion for reconsideration, Gobbi requested additional time to file her motion â€œuntil another judge is assigned.Â  At which time, the issues presented to Judge Lockemy should be revisited.â€Â  Based on this statement, we question whether Gobbi waived any right to challenge Judge Cottinghamâ€™s authority to rule on her motion.Â  
In any event, we find the proper procedure was followed pursuant to Rule 63, SCRCP.Â  By his order dated April 14, 2003, Judge Lockemy informed the parties that he was being deployed for active military duty on April 21, 2003, and requested that the case be assigned to another circuit court judge.Â  Pursuant to this request, the Chief Administrative Judge assigned the case to Judge Cottingham.Â  At the hearing on January 5, 2004, Judge Cottingham again informed the parties that he would hear the outstanding motions because Judge Lockemy was unavailable to preside over the case.Â  Because Judge Lockemy was â€œunable to perform the duties to be performed by the court,â€ we hold Judge Cottingham had authority to hear the partiesâ€™ outstanding motions.Â  See Ness v. Eckerd Corp., 350 S.C. 399, 403, 566 S.E.2d 193, 196 (Ct. App. 2002) (applying Rule 63, SCRCP and finding that another circuit court judge should have heard partyâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion where original circuit court judge denied partyâ€™s motion to set aside an entry of default and then recused himself before ruling on the Rule 59(e) motion).
II.
Gobbi argues Judge Cottingham erred in refusing to grant her motion to enlarge the time to file a motion for reconsideration of Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders.Â  She contends the motion was valid and properly presented to Judge Lockemy and the Chief Administrative Judge. Â We disagree.
Rule 59(e) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides, â€œA motion to alter or amend the judgment shall be served not later than 10 days after receipt of written notice of the entry of the order.â€Â  This ten-day time limit may not be extended.Â  See Rule 6(b), SCRCP (â€œThe time for taking any action under Rules 50(b), 52(b), 59, and 60(b) may not be extended except to the extent and under the conditions stated in them.â€); Leviner v. Sonoco Prods. Co., 339 S.C. 492, 494, 530 S.E.2d 127, 128 (2000) (â€œUnder Rule 59(e), SCRCP, the trial judge has only ten days from entry of judgment to alter or amend an earlier order on his own initiative absent a â€˜reservationâ€™ of jurisdiction in the form order.â€); see also Citizens & S. Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina v. Easton, 310 S.C. 458, 460, 427 S.E.2d 640, 641 (1993) (holding â€œtrial court was without authority to order a new trial beyond 10 days after entry of judgment, regardless of the pendency of the Rule 50(b) motionâ€).Â Â  
In the instant case, Judge Lockemy issued orders dated February 14, 2003, and April 14, 2003.Â  Gobbi did not file a motion for reconsideration within the ten-day limit.Â  Instead, she waited until May 9, 2003, to file a motion to enlarge the time to file the motion for reconsideration.Â  As evidenced by the above-outlined rules of procedure and case law interpreting the rules, Judge Cottingham lacked jurisdiction to enlarge the time for Gobbi to file a motion for reconsideration.Â  Therefore, we find Judge Cottingham properly denied Gobbiâ€™s motion and affirmed Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders.
To the extent that Gobbi argues the ten-day time limit was tolled because Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders were, in her assessment, interlocutory, we find this argument is not preserved for our review.Â  A review of Gobbiâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion challenging Judge Cottinghamâ€™s order reveals that Gobbi did not raise this argument.Â  Thus, she is raising it for the first time on appeal.Â  Accordingly, we decline to address this argument.Â  See 
Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (recognizing that in order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, with few exceptions, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court); see also Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 502, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting an issue is not preserved where the trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument and the appellant does not make a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment).
III.
Finally, Gobbi asserts Judge Cottinghamâ€™s order should be â€œdeemed a nullityâ€ because she was not given proper notice of what would be considered at the hearing.Â  We disagree.
We find Gobbiâ€™s assertion to be without merit.Â  Gobbi filed her motion entitled â€œMotion to Enlarge Time Pursuant to Rule 6(b), to move for reconsideration pursuant to Rule 59(e), on the Basis of Rule 43(I), for a Stay Pursuant to Rule 62(b), and for Service of the Order Recusing Judge Breeden in this Matter Pursuant to Rule 5(b)â€ on May 9, 2003.Â  Judge Cottingham held the hearing on January 5, 2004, which would appear to be sufficient time for Gobbi to prepare to argue her motion.Â  At the hearing, Judge Cottingham inquired whether Gobbi had received a copy of the roster listing the pending motions to be considered at the hearing.Â  Although Gobbi acknowledged receiving the roster, she questioned whether her motion to reconsider was in fact listed as a pending motion. Â Based on our review of the record, we find Gobbi was apprised of what she would be asked to argue at the January 2004 hearing before Judge Cottingham.Â  Therefore, we find Judge Cottingham properly considered Gobbiâ€™s motion at the hearing.
CONCLUSION
Because Judge Lockemy was unable to continue to preside over the case after he issued the order dated April 14, 2003, we find Judge Cottingham had jurisdiction to rule on the partiesâ€™ outstanding motions.Â  Furthermore, we hold Judge Cottingham properly declined to grant Gobbiâ€™s motion to enlarge the time to file a motion for reconsideration.Â  Given there was no timely motion for reconsideration filed, we find Judge Cottingham correctly upheld Judge Lockemyâ€™s orders and concluded Gobbi failed to comply with the mandates of these orders.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â Â  We note that Rule 63 was amended by order dated April 28, 2004.Â  The amended version of the rule provides:

If at any time after a trial or hearing has been commenced, but before the final order or judgment has been issued, the judge is unable to proceed, a successor judge shall be assigned. The successor judge may proceed upon certifying familiarity with the record and determining that the proceedings may be completed without prejudice to the parties. In a hearing or a trial without a jury, the successor judge shall, at the request of a party, recall any witness whose testimony is material and disputed and who is available to testify without undue burden. A successor judge may also provide for the recall of any witnesses.

Rule 63, SCRCP.Â  Because the amendment took effect after Judge Cottingham was assigned to the case in January 2004, we cite to the earlier version of the rule.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jara Uzenda Gobbi, Appellant,
v.
Marjorie Simerman and Patrick Wayne Mumford, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion 2006-UP-246
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 16, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jara Uzenda Gobbi, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Arrigo P. Carotti, Mary Ruth M. Baxter, John B. McCutchein, Jr., all of Conway and Marjorie Simerman, of N. Myrtle Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jara Uzenda Gobbi appeals the trial judgeâ€™s dismissal of her legal malpractice action against attorneys Marjorie Simerman and Patrick Wayne Mumford.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In early 2000, Gobbi retained the services of Simerman for a family court matter.Â  Simerman referred Gobbi to Mumford for representation regarding Gobbiâ€™s allegations of fraudulent conveyance of some of her real estate holdings.Â  On June 17, 2002, Gobbi initiated a malpractice action against both attorneys by filing a summons and complaint alleging breach of contract, negligence, negligent misrepresentation, breach of fiduciary duty, fraud, conversion, and intentional infliction of emotional and financial harm.Â  Although Gobbi correctly identified Mumford in the caption of the summons, Gobbi transposed Mumfordâ€™s first and middle name in the caption of the complaint, listing him as â€œWayne Patrick Mumford,â€ instead of â€œPatrick Wayne Mumford.â€Â  On June 21, 2002, Gobbi filed an amended complaint that correctly identified Mumford as â€œPatrick Wayne Mumford.â€Â  A sheriffâ€™s deputy personally served Mumford on September 16, 2002, and personally served Simerman on September 27, 2002.Â  Both Mumford and Simerman filed answers, generally denying that they were liable to Gobbi for any professional action or inaction on their parts.Â  Mumford additionally asserted affirmative defenses including waiver, estoppel, laches, unconstitutionality of punitive damages, and failure of the complaint to state a cause of action.Â  In her answer, Simerman also requested: the dismissal of the complaint for failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action; judgment on the pleadings; and sanctions and costs from
Gobbi.    
Both attorneys filed motions to dismiss the action.Â  Simermanâ€™s motion urged dismissal pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, for failure to state a cause of action, and for judgment on the pleadings pursuant to Rule 12(c), SCRCP.Â  Mumford moved to dismiss the action pursuant to the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2) (lack of jurisdiction over the person); 12(b)(4) (insufficiency of process); 12(b)(5) (insufficiency of service of process); 12(b)(6) (failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action); and 12(b)(8) (another action is pending between the same parties).Â  Mumford alleged in his affidavit that he was never served with the original summons and complaint and he had only been served with the amended complaint by mail.Â Â  
A hearing was held on both attorneysâ€™ motions to dismiss.Â  A different attorney in the same office as Mumfordâ€™s attorney appeared on Mumfordâ€™s behalf.Â  Mumfordâ€™s attorney moved to dismiss based upon the insufficiency of the process.Â  The trial judge orally granted the motion to dismiss the action against Mumford without prejudice, ruling that it was improper for Gobbi to have served the amended complaint without having served the original complaint.Â  When Gobbi claimed that she served the original complaint by certified mail, the judge noted that was not sufficient.Â  Simerman, representing herself, argued the action should be dismissed for failure to state a claim.Â  After being informed by Mumfordâ€™s attorney that Simerman was served the same way, the judge dismissed the action against her without prejudice, noting that service by mail was insufficient.Â  The judge issued a form order dismissing the action without prejudice against both attorneys for â€œimproper service.â€Â  Gobbi moved for reconsideration, arguing:Â  the service of the amended complaint was proper; the judge should rule on an outstanding motion to file in forma pauperis; and the judge should comment on a report of felonies.Â  The motion was denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  DismissalÂ  (Appellantâ€™s Issues 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, and 9)
Gobbi argues the trial judge erred in dismissing her complaint against both attorneys without prejudice.Â  She asserts the judgeâ€™s decision was erroneous because it amounted to ordering what had already been done.[2]Â  
Under Rule 4(d)(1), SCRCP, personal service may be made upon an individual â€œby delivering a copy of the summons and complaint to him personally or by leaving copies thereof at his dwelling house or usual place of abode with some person of suitable age and discretion then residing therein.â€Â  Service may also be made by certified mail, return receipt requested, and delivery restricted to the addressee.Â  Rule 4(d)(8), SCRCP.Â  There is a presumption of proper service when the rules of civil procedure are followed.Â  Roberson v. S. Fin. of South Carolina, 365 S.C. 6, 10, 615 S.E.2d 112, 114-15 (2005).Â  However, it is still the plaintiffâ€™s burden to show that the court has personal jurisdiction over the defendants.Â  Fassett v. Evans, 364 S.C. 42, 47, 610 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
There is ample evidence in the record to support the trial judgeâ€™s decision to dismiss the action without prejudice.Â  Despite Gobbiâ€™s assertions that she served Simerman and Mumford via certified mail with the original summons and complaint, there was no proof of that service in the record.Â  As the trial judge noted, service by certified mail alone, without restricting delivery or attaching a return receipt, is not sufficient to satisfy Rule 4(d)(8), SCRCP.Â  The rules also require service of the summons and complaint.Â  Therefore, the service by the sheriffâ€™s deputy of the amended complaint, without a summons attached, was insufficient for personal service under Rule 4(d)(1), SCRCP.Â  Although Gobbi argues the service of the amended complaint amounted to proper service, she failed to comply with the service requirements of Rules 4(d)(1) or 4(d)(8), SCRCP, and dismissal of the action without prejudice was proper.Â  
II.Â  Propriety of Dismissal as to SimermanÂ  (Appellantâ€™s Issues 4 and 5)
Gobbi argues it was improper for the trial judge to dismiss the action against attorney Simerman because only the attorney representing Mumford raised and argued the service issue.Â  Further, Gobbi complains that the attorney speaking on behalf of Mumford at the hearing was not the attorney of record and should not have been allowed to speak.Â Â  
Arrigo P. Carotti was Mumfordâ€™s attorney of record.Â  John B. McCutcheon, an attorney in Carottiâ€™s firm, appeared on Mumfordâ€™s behalf in place of Carotti.Â  Although Simerman argued the action should be dismissed against her because the complaint failed to state facts sufficient to support any cause of action, the judge eventually dismissed the action against her after Mumfordâ€™s attorney informed the judge that both attorneys were not sufficiently served with process.Â  Gobbi did not object to Carottiâ€™s appearance or to the judgeâ€™s decision to dismiss the action against Simerman based upon a ground she did not argue.Â  Because these issues were not argued before the trial judge, they are not preserved for appellate review.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000).[3]
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the trial judgeâ€™s decision to dismiss Gobbiâ€™s complaints against Simerman and Mumford without prejudice is
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Gobbi also argues the trial judge erred in dismissing the complaint because: (1) she was denied the opportunity to present evidence at the hearing; (2) she was denied the opportunity to be heard; (3) Simerman and Mumford were barred from moving to dismiss the action based on the insufficiency of service of process after they failed to raise the affirmative defense in their answers and they personally appeared; (4) the order failed to specify the basis for the dismissal, depriving Gobbi of â€œremedial relief;â€ and (5) she was prejudiced by the expiration of the statute of limitations.Â  These arguments were not raised before the trial judge or in her motion for reconsideration.Â  Because these issues were not raised to or ruled upon by the trial judge, they are not preserved for appellate review and we decline to address them.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding that issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial judge are not preserved for appellate review). 
[3]Â  Gobbi also argues that Judge Cottingham erred by not commenting on a document she filed entitled â€œReport to Judge Cottingham Pursuant to USCA Title 18 Sec. 3 and 4 Misprision of Felony and Accessory After the Fact.â€Â  In this document, Gobbi alleged that Mumford and Simerman violated federal law because they had knowledge of the felonies Scott Gobbi was committing and both failed to take action.Â  Gobbi claimed that she was reporting the negligence of both attorneys to the trial judge for him to report to the proper authorities pursuant to federal law.Â  Because we affirm Judge Cottinghamâ€™s dismissal of this action, we need not address the failure to comment on this report.Â

title: State v. Hastings
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Samuel Junior Hastings, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-247
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert Clyde Childs, III, of Greenville, for Appellant. 
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Christina Theos Adams, of Anderson, for Respondent. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Samuel J. Hastings appeals from his convictions on two counts of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Hastings challenges: (1) the admission of two bloodstained shirts, owned by one of the victims, which were not provided to him for inspection prior to trial; (2) admission of color photographs of a victimâ€™s injuries; and (3) comments by the trial judge during sentencing, which Hastings maintains indicate improper consideration of his exercise of the rights to a jury trial and to testify in his own defense.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
On the night of August 31, 2003, a group of regulars were dancing at a bar known as Cadillac Ranch in Oconee County.Â  Hastings and his wife were at the bar, drinking and dancing.Â  One of the women testified that while she was dancing with friends, Hastings bumped into her repeatedly.Â  The woman noticed that Hastings appeared intoxicated, and his wife was attempting to pull him away.Â  The woman tapped Hastings on the shoulder and asked him to stop bumping her.Â  In response, Hastings grabbed the woman on the rear end with both hands, in full view of all of her friends.Â  
The woman told Hastings not to do it again and moved to another section of the dance floor.Â  Hastings then began bumping into another woman.Â  Hastingsâ€™ wife left the dance floor in frustration.Â  By then several bouncers had taken note of the situation, and Hastings was instructed to calm down and leave the dance floor.Â  Hastings began cursing and, in the ensuing confusion, he hit a woman in the face with his fist.Â  
The bouncers immediately sought to contain Hastings by forcing him to the floor and holding his arms and legs.Â  Hastings drew a knife and lunged at them several times.Â  As a result, one bouncer was cut several times on his stomach, and another received severe injuries to his leg which required emergency medical treatment and resulted in permanent scarring.Â  
A jury convicted Hastings on two counts of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  The trial judge sentenced him to ten years suspended on service of four years and five yearsâ€™ probation on both counts, to run concurrently.Â  This appeal follows. 
LAW/ANALYSIS1.
Admission of the Bloody Shirts
      Hastings first argues that the trial judge erred in admitting into evidence two shirts one of the victims was wearing on the night the incident occurred.Â  The shirts were in the possession of the victim until the day of trial.Â  Hastings contends this evidence should have been suppressed because he was not allowed to inspect the shirts pursuant to Rule 5(a)(1)(C), SCRCrimP.Â  We find no reversible error.Â 
        Rule 5(a)(1)(C) of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure provides as follows: 

        Upon request of the defendant the prosecution shall permit the defendant to inspect . . . tangible objects . . . which are within the possession, custody or control of the prosecution, and which are material to the preparation of his defense or are intended for use by the prosecution as evidence in chief at the trial . . . .

        The trial judge may, among other things, suppress evidence at trial that has been withheld in violation of Rule 5.Â  Rule 5(d)(2), SCRCrimP.Â  The decision to admit evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial court, and may only be reversed on a finding of abuse of discretion.Â 
        State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App 2003).Â  Furthermore, any such abuse of discretion must result in prejudice to the defendant.Â 
        State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 77, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
        At trial, the State sought to introduce an undershirt and outer shirt worn by one of the bouncers.Â  The shirts were cut and stained with blood.Â  Hastings, in discovery, had been provided with photographs of the shirts.Â  Counsel for Hastings objected on the ground that no blood could be seen on the shirts in photographs that had been provided in response to his Rule 5 request.Â  It is uncontested that the shirts were in the possession of the witness until the day of trial, but Hastings argued the items of clothing were under the â€œcontrolâ€ of the prosecution within the meaning of Rule 5(a)(1)(C), and therefore, the shirts should have been provided.Â  The trial judge denied Hastingsâ€™ motion to suppress based on his awareness of the existence of the shirts prior to trial.Â  
        Hastings argues on appeal that this ruling deprived him of the opportunity to do a blood test on the shirts.Â  In response, the State argues that evidence in the possession of a witness is not discoverable under Rule 5.Â  See State v. Gulledge, 326 S.C. 220, 226-27, 487 S.E.2d 590, 593 (1997) (finding no discovery violation where the evidence was in the possession of a third party corporation and thus not â€œwithin the possession, custody or control of the prosecutionâ€).Â  This rule, however, should not be used as a vehicle for avoiding discovery by the prosecution.Â  In Gulledge, the records were voluminous and some confusion occurred as to who was to copy the records.Â  Id. at 225-26, 487 S.E.2d at 592-93.Â  
        This case is quite different, as the shirts could easily have been provided.Â  The State certainly had access to the shirts, as evidenced by the photographs it furnished to counsel for Hastings.Â  We find the shirts were within the â€œcontrolâ€ of the State.
        The State further argues that its â€œopen fileâ€ policy satisfied the inspection requirement.Â  See State v. Newell, 303 S.C. 471, 475-76, 401 S.E.2d 420, 423 (Ct. App. 1991). Â Because all agree the shirts were not in the prosecutionâ€™s possession, however, a search of the file would not have discovered the shirts.Â  
        The better practice would have been for the State to turn over the evidence.Â  We find no reversible error because Hastings cannot show prejudice as a result of admission of the shirts.Â  This evidence was merely cumulative of other evidence, such as the pictures of the bouncerâ€™s stomach and the testimony of the bouncer, his wife, and other witnesses.Â  Moreover, because Hastings had photographs of the shirts, he must bear some responsibility in failing to request an opportunity to inspect the shirts.Â  In any event, any error was surely harmless due to the weight of the evidence adduced at trial.Â  State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 194, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990) (â€œError is harmless when it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€).Â  
        2. Color Photograph of the Victimâ€™s injuries
        Hastings next argues that color photographs of the injuries to the other bouncerâ€™s legs should have been suppressed under Rule 403, SCRE, because they were more prejudicial than the black and white photographs.Â  We disagree. 
        â€œIt is well settled that evidence should be excluded when its probative value is outweighed by its prejudicial effect.â€Â  State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 177, 460 S.E.2d 368, 370 (1995).Â  â€œThe determination of the relevancy and materiality of a photograph is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  Id.Â  Moreover, a trial judgeâ€™s considerable latitude in so ruling will not be disturbed absent a showing of probable prejudice.Â  State v. Kornahrens, 290 S.C. 281, 288, 350 S.E.2d 180, 185 (1986).Â  â€œTo constitute unfair prejudice, the photographs must create a tendency to suggest a decision on an improper basis, commonly, though not necessarily, an emotional one.â€Â  State v. Rosemond, 335 S.C. 593, 597, 518 S.E.2d 588, 590 (1999).Â  
        In the instant case the photographs had some probative value as to the juryâ€™s consideration of the greater offense of assault and battery with intent to kill and the lesser included offense of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Tate v. State, 351 S.C. 418, 427, 570 S.E.2d 522, 527 (2002) (holding that ABHAN is the unlawful act of violent injury to another accompanied by circumstances of aggravation, such as use of a deadly weapon).Â  The trial found that the color photographs depicted the wounds better than the black and white ones did.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in admitting the photographs.Â  See, e.g., State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 257-259, 609 S.E.2d 572, 591-92 (Ct. App. 2005) (finding no abuse of discretion in the admission of graphic post-mortem photographs because they were necessary to depict the severity of the injuries and the discoloration of the bruises); State v. Jarrell, 350 S.C. 90, 106-107, 564 S.E.2d 362, 371 (Ct. App. 2002) (upholding the admission of graphic autopsy photographs because they corroborated testimony and demonstrated the extent of the injuries).Â  
        3. Trial Judgeâ€™s Comments during Sentencing 
        Hastings submits two final arguments, both of which derive from the trial judgeâ€™s comments during sentencing.Â  Hastings did not lodge any contemporaneous objections.Â  Accordingly, these issues are not preserved for review.Â  State v. text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ben Rabon and Cynthia Rabon, Respondents,
v.
South Carolina Department of Highways and Public Transportation, South Carolina Insurance Reserve Fund, and American Southern Insurance Company,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-251
Heard April 5, 2006 â€“ Filed May 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Andrew F. Lindemann, of Columbia, for Appellants.Â  
Dennis N. Cannon, Jr., of Camden, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The South Carolina Department of Highways and Public Transportation appeals the trial courtâ€™s order enforcing a settlement agreement.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
Ben Rabon and his wife, Cynthia, brought a claim against the department for injuries Ben sustained in an automobile accident involving an employee of the department.Â  The department was insured by the South Carolina Insurance Reserve Fund.Â  American Southern Insurance Company was the Insurance Reserve Fundâ€™s servicing reinsurer (hereinafter collectively referred to as the department).Â  
On August 17, 1994, the Rabons and Carroll Barwick, a claims adjuster engaged by the department, attended a settlement conference.Â  At the conference, the parties agreed to settle the Rabonsâ€™ claim for a lump sum of $25,000 and an annuity of $650 per month for fifteen years.Â  The Rabons signed a handwritten document containing these terms.Â  The document was not signed by Barwick or any representative from the insurance company.Â  Galaher Settlements Company, a structured settlement company engaged by American Southern to administer the settlement, confirmed the above settlement terms with American Southern by letter dated August 18, 1994.Â  
Following the conference, the Rabons had misgivings about the agreement.Â  Ben testified that, â€œwithin the next day or two,â€ Cynthia called Barwick to explain their dissatisfaction.Â  Cynthia testified she called Barwick â€œjust a couple of days afterâ€ the conference.Â  Cynthia allegedly asked Barwick whether the insurance company could either provide more money up front or extend the annuity payments.Â  Cynthia testified Barwick said he would speak with the other parties about the Rabonsâ€™ concerns.Â  Barwick testified he did not â€œspecifically recallâ€ speaking with the Rabons about changing the agreement.Â  
The Rabons received a $25,000 check issued August 19, 1994 as the lump sum portion of the settlement.Â  They marked out the language on the check indicating â€œfinal settlementâ€ and negotiated the check.Â  The Rabons and William Lynch, a representative of American Southern, initialed the modification.Â  
On September 13, 1994, the Rabons received a proposed settlement agreement via facsimile from Barwick.Â  The proposed agreement provided for the $25,000 lump sum payment and monthly payments of $650 for twenty years.Â  On September 15, 1994, the Rabons met at Barwickâ€™s office to sign the agreement.Â  Ben testified they went over the entire agreement together â€œword for word.â€Â  Cynthia testified they reviewed the agreement thoroughly and she was â€œsureâ€ that the change from fifteen to twenty years was discussed, although she could not â€œsay specifically that that happened.â€Â  The Rabons and Barwick signed the agreement.Â  
By letter dated September 20, 1994, Barwick transmitted the agreement to Galaher Settlements and copied Lynch.Â  On December 24, 1994, Galaher notified Barwick that the contract â€œmistakenlyâ€ provided for periodic payments for twenty years rather than fifteen years.Â  The Rabons were not notified of the alleged mistake.Â  
On September 8, 1997, Galaher sent a letter to American Southern indicating the periodic payments were incorrectly stated on the agreement and the annuity contract would not be issued until the appropriate corrections were made.[1]Â  The letter contained lines for Barwick, Ben Rabon, and American Southern to sign to confirm the mistake.Â  Ben did not sign the September 8, 1997 letter.Â  
By letter dated February 18, 1998, Galaher advised Ben that the annuity would not be issued until he signed a letter agreeing that the annuity term should have been $650 per month for fifteen years.Â  Ben did not sign this letter.Â  
In January of 1999, Galaher notified American Southern that after several failed attempts to secure Benâ€™s signature, the policy would be issued with the existing documentation.Â  A copy of the annuity contract, the agreement, a surety bond, and a Uniform Qualified Assignment were enclosed.Â  A copy of the letter was sent to Ben.Â  
On March 16, 1999, the Rabons informed American Southern of their disagreement with the contents of the January 1999 letter and that they were standing by the terms of the September 15, 1994 agreement.Â  The Rabons received no response.Â  
Sometime in 2001, Ben sought to have his monthly annuity payments deposited directly into his checking account.Â  At that time, Ben obtained a copy of the annuity contract.Â  The contract authorized only fifteen years of monthly payments.Â  
In August of 2002, the Rabons commenced this action seeking specific performance of the September 15, 1994 agreement.Â  The department counterclaimed for reformation as a result of a mutual mistake.Â  The trial court found no mutual mistake and rejected the departmentâ€™s equitable defenses.Â  The court ordered the department to specifically perform the terms of the agreement.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for specific performance is an equitable action.Â  Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Associates, 340 S.C. 98, 105, 531 S.E.2d 287, 290 (2000).Â  An action to reform or set aside a written instrument based upon mutual mistake is also an action in equity.Â  Gecy v. Prudential Ins. Co. of America, 273 S.C. 437, 441, 257 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1979).
In an action in equity, tried by the judge alone, this court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.Â 
Settlemeyer v. McCluney, 359 S.C. 317, 320, 596 S.E.2d 514, 516 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require an appellate court to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact that the trial judge is in the better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â 
Pinckney v. Warren, 344 S.C. 382, 387, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001).Â  


LAW/ANALYSIS


  I.Â  Mutual Mistake
    The department contends the trial court erred in ordering specific performance of the terms of the September 15, 1994 agreement because the agreement was a result of a mutual mistake.Â  We disagree.Â  
    â€œ[A] contract may be avoided or reformed on the ground of mutual mistake of fact where the mistake is common to both parties and, by reason of it, each has done what neither intended.â€Â 
    Chet Adams Co. v. James F. Pedersen Co., 308 S.C. 410, 413, 418 S.E.2d 337, 339 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  However, â€œ[b]efore equity will reform an instrument, it must be shown by evidence which is most clear and convincing not simply that it was a mistake on the part of one of the parties but that it was a mutual mistake.â€Â  Sims v. Tyler, 276 S.C. 640, 642, 281 S.E.2d 229, 230 (1981).Â  
    In our view the evidence does not demonstrate a mutual mistake.Â  There is no clear and convincing evidence the Rabons mistakenly agreed to the terms of the September 15, 1994 agreement.Â  First, the rudimentary handwritten note resulting from the August 17, 1994 settlement conference indicates the parties anticipated a more refined document would follow.Â  Also, the record indicates the Rabons believed the August 17, 1994 proposal was not final.Â  This understanding is evidenced by their testimony and further supported by the Rabons eliminating language on the $25,000 check that indicated the lump sum payment was a final settlement.Â  Finally, the Rabons testified they knew the September 15, 1994 agreement provided them with twenty years of monthly annuity payments and agreed to the settlement based on these terms.Â  Thus, the record does not support a finding of a mistake on the Rabonsâ€™ part even if there was a unilateral mistake on the part of the department.Â  Accordingly, we hold the trial court did not err in finding no mutual mistake.Â  
II.Â  Laches
    The department and the Rabons each raised the equitable defense of laches.Â  The department argues the trial court erred in finding laches barred the departmentâ€™s reformation counterclaim but did not bar the Rabonsâ€™ claim for specific performance.Â  We disagree. 
    Whether a claim is barred by laches is to be determined in light of the facts of each case.Â  Arceneaux v. Arrington, 284 S.C. 500, 503, 327 S.E.2d 357, 358 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  To prove laches, a party must establish:Â  (1) delay, (2) unreasonable delay, and (3) prejudice.Â  Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C. 195, 199, 371 S.E.2d 525, 528 (1988).Â  â€œThe court is vested with wide discretion in determining what is an unreasonable delay.â€Â 
    Chambers of South Carolina, Inc. v. County Council for Lee County, 315 S.C. 418, 421, 434 S.E.2d 279, 280 (1993).Â  
    We agree with the trial court that the Rabonsâ€™ claim for specific performance is not barred by laches because the Rabonsâ€™ failure to bring this action until August of 2002 does not constitute an unreasonable delay.Â  The record demonstrates the Rabons believed the September 15, 1994 agreement established the terms of the settlement and, thus, the Rabons had no reason to sue for specific performance.Â  The Rabons continued to receive monthly annuity payments pursuant to the agreement and were under no obligation to preempt the issue.Â  In fact, the Rabons may have been justified in delaying any cause of action until the department breached the agreement by ceasing payments after fifteen years.Â  We agree with the trial courtâ€™s finding that laches does not bar the Rabonsâ€™ claim for specific performance.Â  
    III.Â  Other issues
    Based on our finding of no mutual mistake, we decline to reach the remaining issues:Â  1) the Rabonsâ€™ defense of laches; 2) the departmentâ€™s claim for reformation barred by equitable estoppel; and 3) the trial courtâ€™s alleged error in finding the department precluded from reformation based on Barwickâ€™s failure to read the agreement.
    Based on the above, we find the trial court did not err in ordering the department to specifically perform the terms of the September 15, 1994 agreement.Â  The decision of the trial court is accordingly 
    AFFIRMED.
    GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.
 


[1]  The record indicates, however, that SAFECO Life Insurance Company issued an annuity on August 23, 1994.Â

text:

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

v.
Gale M. Lyons, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Walter B. Brown, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-252
Submitted April 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gale M. Lyons, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Douglas Kosta Kotti, of Columbia, and John M. Hunter, Jr., of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic action, Gale Lyons (Wife) appeals the order of the family court denying her request for alimony and health insurance.Â  Wife also contends the family court failed to properly value the marital property.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
Wife and Richard Lyons (Husband) married in August of 1997 and separated on March 5, 2001.Â  During the marriage, Husband worked as a corrections officer, first with the South Carolina Department of Corrections and then, beginning in August of 1998, with the Federal Bureau of Prisons.Â  Initially, Wife worked as an administrative assistant and later as a claims adjustor for Sedgwick Insurance.Â  Due to various health problems, Wife left her employment at Sedgwick in 2001.Â  Wife has applied for disability benefits but has not yet been approved.Â  
On March 6, 2003, Husband filed for divorce in Aiken County on the ground of one year separation.Â  Wife answered and counterclaimed for divorce on the ground of adultery and requested the case be transferred to Richland County.Â  Wife then amended her pleadings, seeking alimony and health insurance coverage.Â  
The Aiken County Family Court transferred the case to Richland County.Â  The family court granted the divorce based upon Husbandâ€™s post-separation adultery.Â  The family court found that Husband and Wife enjoyed a modest standard of living during the marriage.Â  Moreover, due in part to the short duration of the marriage[2] and Wifeâ€™s ability to provide for herself, the family court found Wife was not entitled to alimony or health insurance coverage provided by Husband.Â  Both parties agreed to equally apportion the only marital property, Husbandâ€™s thrift savings plan valued at $13,528.85, and agreed to pay their own costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings, and we remain mindful of the fact the family court, which saw and heard the parties, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Pendergast v. Pendergast, 354 S.C. 32, 36, 579 S.E.2d 530, 532 (Ct. App. 2003). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wife contends the family court erred in denying her request for alimony and health insurance.Â  Wife argues the family court failed to give proper consideration to the partiesâ€™ relative financial status and the lifestyle Wife became accustomed to during the marriage.Â  We disagree.Â  
Alimony is a substitute for the support that is normally incident to the marital relationship, and its purpose is to place the supported spouse close to the position of support enjoyed during the marriage.Â  See Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The decision to grant or deny alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Williams v. Williams, 297 S.C. 208, 210, 375 S.E.2d 349, 350 (Ct. App. 1988) (citing McKnight v. McKnight, 283 S.C. 540, 324 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1984)).Â  Section 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2005) of the South Carolina Code lists the factors the family court should consider in deciding whether to award alimony: 

(1) the duration of the marriage and the ages of the parties at the time of the marriage and at separation; (2) the physical and emotional condition of each spouse; (3) the educational background of each spouse and the need for additional education; (4) the employment history and earning potential of each spouse; (5) the standard of living established during the marriage; (6) the current and reasonably anticipated income of each spouse; (7) the current and reasonably anticipated expenses of each spouse; (8) the marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) the custody of any children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) the tax consequences of the award; (12) the existence of support obligations to a former spouse; and (13) such other factors the court considers relevant.

However, no single factor should be considered dispositive of the issue of alimony.Â  Lide v. Lide, 277 S.C. 155, 157, 283 S.E.2d 832, 833 (1981).Â  
In denying Wife alimony and health insurance, the family court noted the partiesâ€™ marriage was one of short duration.Â  In the divorce decree, the family court stated the standard of living established during the marriage was not extravagant.Â  The court elaborated â€œ[t]he parties never owned a home during the marriage and lived in a series of apartments, possibly as many as four . . . .Â  The parties did not take extravagant trips and did not have a lavish life style.â€Â  The only asset of the marriage was Husbandâ€™s thrift savings plan, valued at $13,528.85, which the parties agreed to divide.Â  The family court also observed Husband drove a 1986 Volkswagen and Wife drove a 2002 vehicle, which she purchased after the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  
The family court found Husband was in good health, and that although Wife did have some health problems, her primary problem was with her hip, which she injured before the marriage.Â  In denying Wife alimony and health insurance, the family court stated Wife did not present sufficient evidence of her disability.Â  See Williamson v. Williamson, 311 S.C. 47, 49-50, 426 S.E.2d 758, 760 (1993) (finding that other than her own testimony, Wife did not present any evidence which would have established the extent of her disability and denying alimony). 
Further, the family court stated Wife worked during the marriage and had the ability to provide for her own needs.Â  Additionally, Husband and Wife also had the same educational background, a high school degree and approximately two years of college.Â  Finally, the family court indicated that although it granted Wife a divorce based upon Husbandâ€™s adultery after the partiesâ€™ separation, Husbandâ€™s adultery did not contribute to or affect the partiesâ€™ decision to separate.Â  Therefore, the family court found Husbandâ€™s conduct was not a significant factor weighing in favor of granting Wife alimony.Â  
The record supports the family courtâ€™s decision.Â  The family court considered all of the pertinent statutory factors in deciding whether to award alimony and health insurance in this case.Â  Again, we reiterate the decision to grant or deny alimony, including an award of health insurance, remains within the sound discretion of the family court.Â  See Williams, 297 S.C. at 210, 375 S.E.2d at 350.Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision to deny Wife alimony or health insurance.Â  
Next, Wife maintains the family court erred in its valuation of Husbandâ€™s thrift savings plan.Â  Wife contends her attorney coerced her into accepting the valuation of $13,528.85, but the correct valuation is $15,250.43.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note Wife did not raise this issue below and therefore it is questionably preserved for appeal.Â  See Holy Loch Distrib., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 24, 531 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2000) (â€œIn order to preserved an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).Â  In any event, when questioned by the court concerning the partiesâ€™ agreement, Wife testified that the terms were fair and the valuation of the plan was accurate.Â  The family court approved the agreement, and it is binding on the parties.Â  See Moseley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 353, 306 S.E.2d 624, 627 (1983) (â€œWith the courtâ€™s approval, the terms [of the agreement] become part of the decree and are binding on the parties and the court.â€).Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in approving a valuation freely and voluntarily agreed upon by both parties. 
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]   We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]   The family court found the parties separated for several months in 1999 then reconciled and separated permanently in 2001.Â

PER CURIAM:  Appellant, Horace Reynolds, Jr., appeals from an order of the family court finding a non-lawyer prepared the legal documents in this matter, thus constituting the illegal practice of law.Â  Reynolds bases his appeal on the family court judgeâ€™s dismissal of his action.Â  In our review, it appears the order continues this matter rather than dismisses it, which is consistent with the trial courtâ€™s oral ruling.Â  â€œIt is well settled that an order granting a continuance is an interlocutory order not involving the merits and is, thus, not directly appealable.â€Â  Walker v. Springs Indus., Inc., 298 S.C. 249, 251, 379 S.E.2d 729, 730 (Ct. App. 1989); Temples v. Ramsey, 285 S.C. 600, 602, 330 S.E.2d 558, 559 (Ct. App. 1985). However, because the handwritten order is not clear, we remand to the family court judge who heard this case for clarification of the status of the case.[1]

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
George Larry Thomas, Appellant,
v.
Kimberly C. Thomas, David Alan Aldridge, and Baby Boy David,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â A. E. â€œGeneâ€ Morehead, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-255
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 19, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Nancy H. Bailey, of Florence, for Appellant. 
David A. Aldridge, of Vidalia, Kathy Price Elmore and Kimberly C. Thomas, both of Florence, for Respondents. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â This is a family court action by George Larry Thomas (Stepfather) against Kimberly Thomas (Mother), David Alan Aldridge (Father) and Baby Boy David (Child) seeking to terminate the parental rights of Father, and to allow Stepfather to adopt Child and change his name.Â  Termination is sought under section 20-7-1572(3) and (4) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) for alleged willful failure to visit and pay child support.Â  Stepfather appeals from the denial of his request.Â  We affirm.[1]  
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Stepfather argues that the family court erred in its findings regarding the timing of Fatherâ€™s visits.Â  We agree that the family court erred in finding that Father visited the child in June of 2003.Â  This error does not affect the result, however, because it neither proves that Fatherâ€™s failure to visit was willful nor demonstrates that termination would be in the best interest of Child.Â  
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Stepfather next challenges the family courtâ€™s finding that Father did not willfully fail to visit Child within the meaning of section 20-7-1572(3).Â  We affirm the family courtâ€™s finding pursuant to the following authorities:Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 608, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003) (holding that the statutory grounds for termination must be proved by clear and convincing evidence); Id. at 610, 582 S.E.2d at 423 (holding that failure to visit must be wilful, which is defined as a â€œconscious indifference to the rights of the childâ€); Hopkins v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 313 S.C. 322, 326, 437 S.E.2d 542, 544 (1993), overruled on other grounds by Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 109, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000) (holding that failure to visit is not grounds for termination where the parent was prevented from seeing the child); accord Wilson v. Higgins, 294 S.C. 300, 304, 363 S.E.2d 911, 914 (Ct. App. 1987), overruled on other grounds by Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 109, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000) (â€œA finding of a wilful failure to visit will not be predicated upon parental conduct that can be reasonably explained.â€).Â  
3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Stepfather further asserts that Fatherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated because he failed to pay child support.Â  Clear and convincing evidence does not support termination on this ground either, based on the following authorities: Boyer v. Boyer, 291 S.C. 183, 186, 352 S.E.2d 514, 516 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œBefore parental rights may be severed, the willful failure to support a child after being requested to do so by the childâ€™s custodian must be established by clear and convincing evidence.â€).Â  Hardy v. Gunter, 353 S.C. 128, 134, 577 S.E.2d 231, 234 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œA finding of willful failure to support will not be predicated upon parental conduct that can be reasonably explained.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (providing that the family court may consider all relevant circumstances, including requests for support and ability of the parent to provide support); Hardy, 353 S.C. at 134-35, 577 S.E.2d at 235 (considering extenuating circumstances in ruling on failure to pay).Â  We find the following cases inapposite to the given situation: S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 256-58, 519 S.E.2d 351, 355-56 (Ct. App. 1999) (wherein the parent failed to visit or support the child over a period of years and the appellate court was reviewing the trial courtâ€™s discretionary finding that termination was warranted); Jamison v. Jamison, 285 S.C. 603, 607, 330 S.E.2d 671, 673 (Ct. App. 1985) (same); Abercrombie v. LaBoon, 290 S.C. 35, 37-38, 348 S.E.2d 170, 171-72 (1986) (wherein an initial finding of abandonment was made, and judicially-motivated repentance stood alone as a factor demonstrating such abandonment had been cured).Â  
4.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Stepfatherâ€™s final argument is that the family court erred in overruling his objection regarding certain testimony by his pastor. The party objecting to disclosure of the information has the burden of showing the privilege applies. The determination whether the privilege applies is committed to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  We find no abuse of discretion and affirm pursuant to the following authorities: Rivers v. Rivers, 292 S.C. 21, 26, 354 S.E.2d 784, 787 (Ct. App. 1987), overruled on other grounds by Russo v. Sutton, 310 S.C. 200, 205, 422 S.E.2d 750, 753 (1992) (holding that four conditions must be established before the clergyman-penitent privilege applies: (1) a confidential communication; (2) the confidential communication must be disclosed to a regular or duly ordained minister, priest, or rabbi; (3) the confidential communication must be entrusted to the clergyman in his professional capacity; and (4) the confidential communication must be one that is necessary and proper to enable the clergyman to discharge the functions of his office according to the usual course of practice or discipline of his church or religious body).Â  We further discern no resulting prejudice from the pastorâ€™s testimony.
5.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We concur with the experienced and able family court judgeâ€™s finding that termination is not in the best interests of Child, a finding to which Stepfather takes no exception.Â  The failure to challenge this finding is an independent basis on which to affirm.Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 419-421, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723-24 (2000) (holding that an appellate court may affirm based on any ground appearing in the record); Parker, 336 S.C. at 258, 519 S.E.2d at 356 (â€œIn a termination of parental rights case, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.â€); S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs.Â  v. Headden, 354 S.C. at 609, 582 S.E.2d at 423 (holding that termination requires both proof of one of the statutory grounds and demonstration that the action is in the best interest of the child). 
AFFIRMED. 
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â Â  

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
