text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Furman Edward Fulmer, Jewel F. Oxner, Carolyn F. Garner, Sandra F.
Metts, and Faye F. Cannon, Respondents,
v.
Janette F. Cain, Appellant.
      
    
  



  
    
      
Jewel Oxner, As the Personal Representative of the Estate of Mary F. Fulmer, deceased,
Respondent,
v.
Janette F. Cain, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-256
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 19, 2006

VACATED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Adele Jeffords Pope, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Pope D. Johnson III, of Columbia; Samuel M. Price, Jr., of Newberry; for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal concerns the probate courtâ€™s refusal to remove a formal testacy action to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court affirmed the denial of the removal.Â  We vacate in part, reverse in part, and remand.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Mary Fulmer died April 29, 2002, at age 88, survived by her six children.Â  In a will dated July 2, 1998, Mrs. Fulmer left her daughter, appellant Janette Cain, 10.59 acres of real estate, with the rest of her real estate to be divided among her other five children and her residuary estate to be equally divided among all six children.Â  She also designated another daughter, respondent Jewel Oxner, to be the personal representative of her estate. 
On December 20, 2002, Oxner, in her capacity as personal representative of Mrs. Fulmerâ€™s estate, filed an action in the probate court against Cain.Â  In her complaint, Oxner sought to set aside the transfer of funds in certain accounts to which Cain and their late mother held joint title, asserted a cause of action for fraud against Cain, and initiated a formal proceeding to set aside a handwritten codicil purportedly executed by Mrs. Fulmer on September 15, 2000,[2] by which she devised additional real property to Cain.Â  Cain counterclaimed for Oxnerâ€™s removal as personal representative, damages for waste, and the issuance of deeds of distribution.Â  Cain did not seek to remove this action to the circuit court.Â  
On February 28, 2003, the respondents in this appealâ€”Oxner and Mrs. Fulmerâ€™s other four childrenâ€”filed a petition in the probate court for formal testacy and other relief, naming Cain as party-defendant.Â  The petition included a jury trial demand.Â  That same day, Respondents filed an addendum to their petition challenging the validity of the codicil and asserting causes of action against Cain for breach of contract and fraud in the inducement, breach of confidential or fiduciary relationship, tortious interference with a contract, and tortious interference with inheritance rights.Â  They also moved to consolidate their action with the case that Oxner had filed on behalf of Mrs. Fulmerâ€™s estate.Â  On March 4, 2003, Cain moved to remove the second action to the circuit court and to dismiss it pursuant to Rule 12(b),
SCRCP.  
After a hearing on July 17, 2003, the probate court (1) granted Respondentsâ€™ motion to consolidate the two actions; (2) denied Cainâ€™s motion to remove the action to the circuit court; and (3) granted Cainâ€™s motion to dismiss the cause of action for interference with an inheritance; (4) otherwise denied Cainâ€™s motion to dismiss.
On cross-appeals from the probate courtâ€™s ruling, the circuit court reversed the dismissal of the cause of action for interference with an inheritance and affirmed the probate courtâ€™s decisions to consolidate the two actions and to deny Cainâ€™s motion to remove the second action to the circuit court.Â  Cain appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Probate Code governs appeals from the probate court.[3]Â  Under South Carolina Code section 62-1-308(a), â€œa person interested in a final order, sentence, or decree of a probate court and considering himself injured by it may appeal to the circuit court in the same county.â€[4]Â  The circuit court, in determining the appeal, must apply the same standard of review as an appellate court would apply.[5]
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Respondents argue the order Cain challenges is interlocutory and does not fall within any of the categories of appealable judgments, decrees, or orders.[6]Â  We agree the order is interlocutory; however, based on our review of the pleadings filed in this case, we conclude it is nevertheless appealable because it has the effect of denying Cain a mode of trial to which she is entitled.[7]
The South Carolina Probate Code provides certain actions filed in the probate court â€œmust be removedâ€ to the circuit court upon a timely motion by â€œany party.â€[8]Â  These actions include â€œformal proceedings for the probate of wills and for the appointment of personal representativesâ€[9] and â€œactions in which a party has a right to trial by jury and which involve an amount in controversy of at least five thousand dollars in value.â€[10]Â  Although, as Respondents argue, jury trials are available in the probate court,[11] the commentary to the pertinent statutory provisions suggests the legislature contemplated that the â€œmode of trialâ€ to which an interested litigant was entitled as a matter of right includes the particular tribunal designated to adjudicate the matter.[12]Â  Unlike a venue order, which affects only the location of the tribunal and is therefore not appealable, the denial of Cainâ€™s motion to remove the matter to the circuit court involves the tribunal itself.Â  Moreover, we cannot overlook the significance of the fact that, although the South Carolina General Assembly in 1988 amended the statute governing jury trials in the probate court to state that â€œ[t]he right to trial by jury exists in, but is not limited to proceedings in favor of the probate of a will or contesting the probate of a will,â€[13] it left the right of removal to the circuit court intact.Â  
2.Â  Respondents contend Cainâ€™s failure to appeal the probate courtâ€™s finding that she had waived her right to remove the second lawsuit by failing to request removal of the first action warrants dismissal of this appeal under the â€œlaw of the caseâ€ doctrine.Â  We disagree.Â  Cainâ€™s motion to remove was based on section 62-1-302, which, as evident from its heading, concerns the â€œ[s]ubject matter jurisdictionâ€ of the probate court.Â  Cainâ€™s alleged failure to appeal the probate courtâ€™s finding of a waiver should not bar her from raising this issue on appeal.[14]Â  In any event, we agree with Cain that her first ground of appeal to the circuit court adequately encompassed the issue of waiver.[15]
3.Â  Respondents further argue Cainâ€™s appeal is moot because their counsel â€œstipulated that if this Court were to remand the consolidated actions to the Probate Court, they would not oppose [Cainâ€™s] removal of the consolidated actions to this Court once the Personal Representative amended her pleadings.â€Â  We disagree.Â  At best, the stipulation would control only Respondentsâ€™ actions.Â  It does not guarantee that the probate court would grant the removal even without opposition from Respondents.Â  Because we are called to determine whether removal to the circuit court was mandatory irrespective of whether there is opposition from another party to the litigation, our judgment, when rendered, will have a â€œpractical legal effect upon [the] existing controversy.â€[16]Â  Contrary, then, to Respondentsâ€™ assertion, Cainâ€™s appeal is not moot.
4.Â  We agree with Cain that the circuit court erred in affirming the probate courtâ€™s denial of her motion for removal.Â  â€œ[N]otwithstanding the exclusive jurisdictionâ€ of the probate court over certain matters, the South Carolina Probate Code specifically allows litigants to request removal of cases pending in the probate court to circuit court.[17]Â  Provided the motion for removal is timely, removal to the circuit court is not a matter of discretion for the probate court; rather, it must occur if the causes of action requested for removal relate to certain subject matters, among them formal proceedings for the probate of wills and the appointment of personal representatives[18] and â€œactions in which a party has a right to a jury trial and which involve an amount in controversy of at least five thousand dollars in value.â€[19]Â  There is no allegation in the present case that Cainâ€™s motion to remove was untimely or that the cause of action for which she sought removal did not relate to at least one of the subject matters enumerated in South Carolina Code section 62-1-302(c).
5.Â  Respondents correctly point out that Cain did not request removal of the action that Oxner filed against her on behalf of the estate.Â  We, however, agree with Cain that this failure does not amount to a waiver of her right to remove the later action that Respondents filed against her.Â  
We agree there may have been some overlap in the issues raised in the two lawsuits.Â  Nevertheless, whereas the initial action was ostensibly brought to recover assets for Mrs. Fulmerâ€™s estate, the second action included a claim by her purported beneficiaries for recovery of actual and punitive damages for themselves, not their motherâ€™s estate.Â  Under these circumstances, the two actions are not related in such a way that Cainâ€™s failure to request removal of the first one would constitute a forfeiture of her right to have the subsequent one transferred to the circuit court pursuant to section 62-1-302.[20]
6.Â  We further agree with Cain that the probate court erred in ruling on any matter other than removal to the circuit court and hold the circuit court should have vacated any such rulings.Â  The probate code expressly requires that, upon removal, the circuit court â€œshall proceed upon the matter de novo.â€[21]Â  
 VACATED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  This date is taken from Oxnerâ€™s complaint.Â  The appealed order states the codicil is stated July 15, 2002, which is inconsistent with the fact that Mrs. Fulmer died April 29, 2002.
[3]Â  Golini v. Bolton, 326 S.C. 333, 337, 482 S.E.2d 784, 786 (Ct. App. 1997).
[4]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308(a) (Supp. 2005).
[5]Â  In re Howard, 315 S.C. 356, 360, 434 S.E.2d 254, 257 (1993); In re Estate of Weeks, 329 S.C. 251, 261, 495 S.E.2d 454, 460 (Ct. App. 1997).
[6]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (1976 and Supp. 2005) (listing the types of cases within the appellate jurisdiction of the supreme court and, presumably, the court of appeals).
[7]Â  See C&S Real Estate Servs. v. Massengale, 290 S.C. 299, 300, 350 S.E.2d 191, 192 (1986) (â€œAn order denying a party a jury trial is not immediately appealable unless it deprives him of a mode of trial to which he is entitled as a matter of right.â€); Truluck v. Snyder, 362 S.C. 108, 113, 606 S.E.2d 792, 794 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding the probate courtâ€™s denial of a motion to have a case considered by a jury in the circuit court impacted the mode of trial and was therefore appealable).
[8]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(c) (1987), as amended, 1990 S.C. Acts 521 Â§ 8 (emphasis added).Â  This subsection was amended in 2005 and redesignated as subsection(d).Â  Because the proceedings at issue in this appeal took place before the 2005 amendments to the probate code, the citations here will be to either the 1987 version of Title 62 or the appropriate volume of the South Carolina Acts and Joint Resolutions.
[9]Â  Id. Â§ 62-1-302(c)(1) (1987).
[10] Id. Â§ 62-1-302(c)(5).
[11] Id. Â§ 62-1-306 (1987 and Supp. 2005).
[12] Most notably, the Reporterâ€™s Comments to South Carolina Code section 62-1-302 state the following:

It should be noted that the probate court has â€œexclusive original jurisdictionâ€ over the matters enumerated in this section.Â  This means, when read with other Code provisions . . . that matters within the original jurisdiction of the probate court must be brought in that court, subject to certain provisions made for removal to the circuit court . . . on the motion of any party. 

Id. Â§ 62-1-302 Reporterâ€™s Comments (1987) (emphasis added).Â  Cf. Glidewell v. Martin, 11 S.W. 882, 885 (Ark. 1889) (stating the word â€œmodeâ€ â€œmeans â€˜placeâ€™ as well as â€˜mannerâ€™ of trialâ€).
[13] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-306 (1987), as amended, 1988 Acts 659, Â§ 4.
[14] See Amisub of S.C. v. Passmore, 316 S.C. 112, 114, 447 S.E.2d 207, 208 (1994) (â€œLack of subject matter jurisdiction may not be waived and should be taken notice of by this Court.â€); Riggs v. Riggs, 353 S.C. 230, 236 n.3, 578 S.E.2d 3, 6 n.3 (Ct. App. 2003) (determining, based on Amisub, that the issue of the family courtâ€™s jurisdiction was properly before the court of appeals).
[15] The ground of appeal is stated as follows:Â  â€œThe Court erred in denying Appellantâ€™s timely filed Motion for Removal of this action to Circuit Court because it was removable under South Carolina Probate Code 62-1-302(c).â€Â  
[16] Mathis v. S.C. State Highway Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E. 2d 713, 715 (1973).
[17] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(c) (1987), as amended, 1990 S.C. Acts 521 Â§ 8.
[18] Id. Â§ 62-1-302(c)(1) (1987).
[19] Id.
Â§ 62-1-302(c)(5).
[20] See id. Â§ 62-1-302(e) (Supp. 2005) (â€œThe removal to the circuit court of an action or proceeding within the exclusive jurisdiction of the probate court applies only to the particular action or proceeding removed, and the probate court otherwise retains exclusive jurisdiction.â€); Cotty v. Yartzeff, 309 S.C. 259, 262, 422 S.E.2d 100, 102 (1992) (â€œUnder the South Carolina Probate Code, except administration under Part 5, â€˜each . . . proceeding before the court is independent of any other proceeding involving the same estate . . . .â€™â€) (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-107 (1987)).
[21] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(c) (1987), as amended, 1990 S.C. Acts 521 Â§ 8.

PER CURIAM: Â On June 25, 2001, the South Carolina Department of Social Services (â€œSCDSSâ€) commenced a child support enforcement action against Gerald Lancaster for the support of his son Broderick.Â  Lancaster appeals the family court order requiring him to pay child support.Â  Â Â

Powell, 256 S.C. 111, 116, 181 S.E.2d 13, 16 (1971) (â€œIt is the duty of all courts to do that which is for the best interest of minor children and to protect their rights at every stage of a proceeding . . . .â€); Jennings v. Dargan, 308 S.C. 317, 321, 417 S.E.2d 646, 648 (Ct. App. 1992) (adopting the general rule that in a conflict between the policy respecting the finality of judgments and the need to adequately protect the rights of minors, the protection of the interests of minors is the overriding concern); 67A C.J.S. Servs. v. Parker, 275 S.C. 176, 178, 268 S.E.2d 282, 283 (1980) (holding the doctrine of estoppel â€œwill not be applied to deprive [SCDSS] of the due exercise of its police power or to thwart its application of public policy.â€); cf. Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 196, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989) (â€œFamily courts are empowered to modify child support upon a proper showing of a change in either the childâ€™s needs or the supporting parentâ€™s financial ability.â€); Walker v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Noisette v. a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the judgment); Fishburne v. Short, 268 S.C. 546, 235 S.E.2d 118 (1977) (ruling an error without prejudice does not warrant reversal).Â  
AFFIRMED.[2]

Partnership, 312 S.C. 102, 106, 439 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œAn issue raised on appeal but not argued in the brief is deemed abandoned and will not be considered by the appellate court.â€); Rule 208(b)(1)(D), SCACR (â€œThe brief shall be divided into as many parts as there are issues to be argued.Â  At the head of each part, the particular issue to be addressed shall be set forth in distinctive type, followed by discussion and citations of authority.â€).

The South Carolina Court of Appeals

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Sharon Smith, Adam Turkvant, Kenneth Grant, John Doe, and Desmond Smith, DOB 6-3-93, John Smith, DOB 9-21-89, Defendants, 
of whom Sharon Smith is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Anne Gue Jones, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-258
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ariel Townsend Rosamond, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.Â  
Jerrod Austin Anderson, of Orangeburg, for Respondent.
Eugene L. Ott, and James B. Jackson, Jr., both of Orangeburg, for Guardian Ad Litem.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Sharon Smith appeals the termination of her parental rights to two of her children, Desmond Smith and John Smith.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The South Carolina Department of Social Services filed suit seeking to terminate the parental rights of Smith.Â  Adam Turkvant, Johnâ€™s father, agreed to the termination of his rights.Â  The termination of Desmondâ€™s fatherâ€™s rights has not been appealed.[2]Â  Desmond and John were removed from Smithâ€™s care when she tested positive for drugs at the time of Desmondâ€™s birth.Â  The boys were placed in the care of their great-grandmother, Maybell Color-Wolf, pursuant to a DSS safety plan.Â  They were removed from Wolfâ€™s care on November 5, 2001 because, at the age of 92 and in failing health, Wolf was unable to appropriately supervise and care for the children.[3]Â  Desmond and John were placed in foster care with a family that is now prepared to adopt both.Â  
Smith appeared at a court hearing regarding the children in November 2001.Â  After the hearing, the family court issued an order requiring Smith to do the following:Â  (a) complete all services [primarily drug counseling] recommended by the Dawn Center, (b) complete parenting classes and follow recommendations, and (c) maintain safe and suitable housing.Â  Smith did not attempt to communicate with anyone at DSS regarding the children again until over a year later in December 2002.Â  In the interim, in August 2002, Smith was incarcerated in a Florida federal prison on drug charges.Â  
While incarcerated, Smith has been employed earning $.68 per hour.Â  She has completed drug counseling and parenting classes.Â  Smith has failed to send any monetary support to Desmond and John other than some pajamas and a book.Â  
DSS filed the underlying TPR action in March 2004.Â  The family court terminated Smithâ€™s parental rights based on a failure to support for six months, failure to remedy the conditions that caused the removal of the children, and their presence in foster care for 15 out of the previous 22 months.Â  Smith appeals the courtâ€™s rulings as to failure to support and failure to comply with her treatment plan.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR case, the paramount consideration is the best interests
of the children.Â  See Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 296, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 (1999).
Â In a TPR case, the appellate court may review the record and make its own findings of whether clear and convincing evidence supports termination.Â  Hardy v. Gunter, 353 S.C. 128, 134, 577 S.E.2d 231, 234 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  However, our broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact that the trial judge was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â 
Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Smith claims the family court erred in finding that she willfully failed to support Desmond and John for a period of six months and failed to comply with her prescribed treatment plan.Â  We disagree.Â  
In support of her argument, Smith points out that she was not under a court order to pay support and that she was incarcerated since August of 2002.Â  While incarceration may limit a parentâ€™s ability to earn, it does not relieve them of the burden to support their child.Â 
South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Phillips, 301 S.C. 308, 310, 391 S.E.2d 584, 585 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  Furthermore, â€œnothing in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(3) & (4) . . . requires a parent be â€˜notifiedâ€™ of [her] duty to support or visit [a child] before failure to discharge those duties may serve as grounds for termination of parental rights.â€Â 
South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 258, 519 S.E.2d 351, 356 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The record shows that Smith was earning $.68 per hour.Â  While that is an admittedly modest sum, the only things she ever sent to the children were pajamas and a book.Â  Additionally, in months immediately preceding her incarceration, Smithâ€™s whereabouts were unknown, and the unrefuted evidence is she provided no support during that time.Â  Based on the record and the applicable statutory provision, we find there is clear and convincing evidence to support the family courtâ€™s determination.
Smith further claims the family court erred in finding that she had not complied with the terms of her treatment plan and remedied the conditions that caused the childrenâ€™s removal from the home.Â  However, the record shows that Smith only attempted to comply with the counseling requirements of her treatment plan after her incarceration and that she had, as of the time of the TPR hearing, failed to obtain stable housing.Â  
As to the best interests of the children, the record shows that their behavior and schoolwork have improved significantly while in foster care.Â  They have established a bond with their foster parents calling them â€œMaâ€ and â€œDaâ€ and, according to their caseworker, are ready to proceed with the process of adoption.Â  
Because there is clear and convincing evidence supporting the family courtâ€™s termination of parental rights and because such action is in the best interest of the children, the ruling of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, STILWELL, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]   We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]   Kenneth Grant and/or John Doe are cited as Desmondâ€™s father.Â  The judge determined that Desmondâ€™s father had failed to support or visit him for greater than six months and that Desmond had lived in foster care for at least 15 of the last 22 months.Â  
[3]   The legal basis for removal was â€œchild abuse or neglectâ€ under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490(2) (Supp. 2005).Â

title: SCDSS v. Henry
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Loretta Henry, Richard Howard, Jr. and Tommie Thornton, Defendants,
IN THE INTEREST OF:
Destiny Howard, DOB: 10/05/90 Richard Howard, IV, DOBÂ  07/14/94
Dakota Howard, DOB: 06/21/97 Crystal Howard, DOB: 12/26/99 Minor Children Under the Age of 18
Of whom Richard Howard, Jr. is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Stephen S. Bartlett, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-259
Heard April 19, 2006 â€“ Filed May 23, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
A.M. Quattlebaum, Jr., of Greenville; for Appellant.
Danielle M. Mitchell, of Greenville; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Richard Howard, Jr., appeals the family courtâ€™s order finding the emergency removal of his children from his home had merit.[1]Â  We reverse and remand. 
FACTS
On January 10, 2005, the Department of Social Services (DSS) was contacted concerning a black eye and cut or scratch on the face of ten-year-old Richard Howard, IV (Son).Â  According to Son and his mother, Loretta Henry (Mother), his injuries were caused when Richard Howard, Jr. (Father) slapped Son on the back of his head, causing him to fall forward and hit his head on the kitchen table.Â  During the DSS investigation, allegations were made that Father trained pit bulls on the familyâ€™s property to fight; had several weapons; was physically and emotionally abusive towards Mother; threatened the life of the childrenâ€™s maternal grandmother; and suffered from bipolar disorder.Â  As a result, Son and his three sisters were taken into emergency protective custody on January 13, 2005.Â Â  
A probable cause hearing was held on January 18, 2005.Â  Mother appeared, but Father was not present because he was involuntarily placed at the Carolina Center for Behavioral Health.Â  The family court issued an order appointing counsel and a guardian ad litem for Father and finding probable cause existed to keep the children in protective custody.Â  The Probable Cause Removal Hearing Order gave the parties notice that a merits hearing would be held on February 15, 2005.Â  A merits removal order was issued on February 15, 2005,[2] and Father was personally served with the order.Â  Included in the order was a notice for the trial date of March 17, 2005.Â Â  
Father failed to appear at the March 17, 2005 hearing because he was incarcerated in federal prison in North Carolina awaiting a mental evaluation.Â  Fatherâ€™s guardian ad litem and appointed counsel appeared on his behalf.Â  Counsel moved for a continuance, arguing that he did not have access to Father and there was no way for Father to participate in the hearing.Â  Counsel stated he was informed that he would not have access to Father until after the mental evaluation, which would be at least four or five months after the hearing.Â  The family court noted the removal statute only allows for a thirty-day continuance and requires the matter to be concluded within sixty-five days.Â  Noting that Father still would be unavailable within thirty days, the matter was already near the sixty-five day mark, and Father had a guardian ad litem, the court denied the request for a continuance.Â  After a hearing on the merits, the court made a finding that Father physically struck Son and placed the other children at substantial risk of abuse.Â  The court also approved Motherâ€™s plea agreement with DSS, finding a substantial risk of abuse to the children based on a failure to protect.Â  The court approved a treatment plan for both parents.Â  The court approved placement of the oldest daughters with their maternal grandmother and placement in foster care for Son and the youngest daughter.Â  Father appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œThis degree of deference is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of a minor child.â€Â  Ex Parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 62, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  Further, this broad scope of review does not relieve the appellant from the burden of showing the family court erred.Â  Id.Â  Whether to grant or deny a motion for a continuance is a matter within the sole discretion of the family court and will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bridwell v. Bridwell, 279 S.C. 111, 112, 302 S.E.2d 856, 858 (1983).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Father argues the family court erred in failing to grant his motion for a continuance because it resulted in a violation of his due process rights.Â  He asserts the merits hearing concerned his fundamental rights as a parent, and thus, he deserved the â€œopportunity to be heard at a meaningful time and in a meaningful manner.â€Â  
In discussing due process rights in removal situations, this court noted as follows:

â€œDue process is a flexible concept, and the requirements of due process in a particular case are dependent upon the importance of the interest involved and the circumstances under which the deprivation may occur.â€Â 
South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Beeks, 325 S.C. 243, 246, 481 S.E.2d 703, 705 (1997).Â  â€œThe fundamental requirement of due process is the opportunity to be heard at a meaningful time and in a meaningful manner.â€Â  Id.  

South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Meek, 352 S.C. 523, 533, 575 S.E.2d 846, 851 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  A parentâ€™s interest in the custody of his or her children is â€œextraordinarily significant,â€ triggering fundamental due process rights to notice and an opportunity to be heard.Â  Meek, 352 S.C. at 534, 575 S.E.2d at 851.Â  
In DSS emergency removal cases, the statute outlines a strict timeline for the judicial process.Â  A probable cause hearing must be held within seventy-two hours of the time the child was taken into protective custody.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-610(M) (Supp. 2005).Â  A hearing on the merits â€œmust be held within thirty-five days of the date of the receipt of the removal petition.â€Â  Id.Â  When read in conjunction with other statutes, our courts have determined this section does not mean that the hearing must be concluded within thirty-five days, but the merits hearing must be scheduled within thirty-five days.Â 
South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Gamble, 337 S.C. 428, 432, 523 S.E.2d 477, 479 (Ct. App. 1999) (reading section 20-7-610(M) in conjunction with section 20-7-736(E), the court found that â€œthe plain language of the statute indicates that a merits hearing must be scheduled to be held within thirty-five days of receipt of the removal petition.Â  The statute does not indicate that the hearing must be completed within the thirty-five day period.Â  Therefore the requirement that a hearing on the merits actually come to a conclusion within thirty-five days of the removal petition should not be read into the statute.â€).Â  
Where exceptional circumstances exist, the family court may grant a continuance:

A party may request a continuance that would result in the hearing being held more than thirty-five days after the petition was filed, and the court may grant the request for continuance only if exceptional circumstances exist.Â  If a continuance is granted, the hearing on the merits must be completed within sixty-five days following receipt of the removal petition.Â  The court may continue the hearing on the merits beyond sixty-five days without returning the child to the home only if the court issues a written order with findings of fact supporting a determination that the following conditions are satisfied, regardless of whether the parties have agreed to a continuance:
  
(1)Â  the court finds that the child should remain in the custody of the department because there is probable cause to believe that returning the child to the home would seriously endanger the childâ€™s physical safety or emotional well-being;
(2)Â  the court schedules the case for trial on a date and time certain which is not more than thirty days after the date the hearing was scheduled to be held; and
(3)Â  the court finds that exceptional circumstances support the continuance or the parties and the guardian ad litem agree to a continuance.
  
The court may continue the case past the date and time certain set forth in subsection (M) only if the court issues a new order as required in subsection (M).

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-610 (M) (Supp. 2005).Â  The plain language of this statute indicates that multiple continuances can be given past the sixty-five day time limit as long as the family court revisits the matter every thirty days, issuing a new order each time.Â  See Gamble, 337 S.C. at 431, 523 S.E.2d at 478 (noting that the legislative intent of a statute must be determined from the language of the statute itself where the statute is complete, plain, and unambiguous).
In denying Fatherâ€™s motion for a continuance in the present case, the family court noted that the parties were nearing the statutory sixty-five day time limit.Â  The court also noted that continuances could be given every thirty days past the sixty-five day time limit:

I would continue it, but I can only do it for 30 days.Â  And quite candidly, it just does not appear thereâ€™s going to be a significant change for anybody in 30, 60, 90 days.Â  And from that standpoint, I donâ€™t see anything to be achieved, or gained, by continuing the case.Â  I have great sympathy for counsel, and understand it puts you in sort of a dilemma that you donâ€™t have a client.Â  But legally, thereâ€™s a guardian appointed, and he is in federal prison, so I believe that the department can go forward.Â  So what Iâ€™m going to do is, Iâ€™m gonna deny the request for a continuance.

Although the decision to grant a continuance normally rests within the broad discretion of the family court, there is not enough in the record to support the denial of the requested continuance in this case.Â  Considering the fact that Father failed to appear at two hearings because he was institutionalized either in a behavioral hospital or in federal prison awaiting a mental evaluation, a continuance of the case against Father would have allowed counsel and the guardian ad litem the opportunity to attempt to meet with Father to discuss the removal case.Â  The family court pointed out, and Fatherâ€™s counsel did not deny, that it was possible Father would not have been available to appear at a hearing within ninety days if the matter was continued.Â  However, there was no further inquiry into the possibility of Father being available for a rescheduled hearing past this initial speculation.Â  
We are mindful of the fact that family courts must proceed as expeditiously as possible in emergency placement cases to protect the welfare of the children.Â  Any continuance of the matter against Father, however, would not have created a risk of harm to the children as they were safely placed either in foster care or with their maternal grandmother pursuant to Motherâ€™s plea agreement.Â  Because the children were not in any danger and Fatherâ€™s counsel seemed unsure of when he could see his client, the family court could have allowed a continuance for further inquiry into the possibility of Fatherâ€™s later appearance.Â  As previously discussed, however, the family court denied Fatherâ€™s motion based on speculation that a continuance would have been futile.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the denial of the continuance and remand the matter for specific findings on whether there was evidence at the time of the hearing that Father would not have been available within the time provided by statute.Â  
CONCLUSION
Under the particular facts of this case, we find the family courtâ€™s order denying Father a continuance of the merits hearing is not supported by the record.Â  Accordingly, the portion of the family courtâ€™s merits order regarding Father is reversed and the matter is remanded to the family court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.[3]  
 REVERSED and REMANDED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Loretta Henry, the mother of the four children, was also a party in the underlying DSS action.Â  She is not a party in this appeal.Â Â  
[2]Â  Although there is no evidence in the record indicating that a merits hearing was held on February 15, 2005, it appears there was such a hearing at which time a continuance was granted.Â  The January 18, 2005 Probable Cause Removal Hearing Order notifies the parties that a hearing was to be held on February 15th.Â  The February 15, 2005 placement plan included in the record references the February 15, 2005 order, which is not in the record.Â  Further, DSSâ€™s brief indicates the original merits hearing was continued until March 17, 2005, to allow appointment of an attorney for Father.Â Â  
[3]Â  Father also argued on appeal that the family court erred in making a finding of abuse.Â  There is evidence in the record to support the removal of the children.Â  We are only reversing and remanding for a hearing to determine whether there were facts to support the denial of the motion for a continuance.Â  If the family court finds there was evidence at the time of the hearing that Father would not have been available after a continuance, then the family courtâ€™s order denying the continuance and making findings to support the removal shall be reinstated.Â  If the court finds there was no evidence that a continuance would have been futile, then a new merits hearing shall be held with regard to Father.Â Â Â Â

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
John Tamorris McClure, Appellant.
      
    
  

Â Â Â  

Appeal from York County
Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-260
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 23, 2006
Â Â  

 AFFIRMED
Â Â  


  
    
      
Hemphill P. Pride II, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: John Tamorris McClure appeals his conviction for possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine.Â  We affirm.[1]
Facts
On April 22, 2004, the Multi-Jurisdictional Drug Enforcement Unit (the Unit) executed a search of a mobile home located at 2447 Holly Road in York County, South Carolina and the immediate surrounding area. Â Prior to that date, the Unit had received complaints of drug activity in that area, which made Holly Road an area of interest.Â  After a police informant made a crack cocaine purchase at the mobile home on Holly Road, the officers noticed further suspicious activity.Â  Several individuals were seen â€œcoming and going, persons driving up and staying less than five minutes, meeting with other persons and then leaving, which is consistent with drug activity.â€ Further, the officers noticed that in the afternoons, people would gather on both sides of the street near the home.Â  
Based on the information obtained from their observations and informant, the officers of the Unit obtained a search warrant for the mobile home. The Unit planned a surveillance of the grassy lot directly across the street. Â â€œConsensual encountersâ€ were to be conducted with people on the grassy lot.Â  During the search, McClure was seated in a car in the grassy lot across the street. While two teams from the Unit went into the house, two other officers parked, without blocking in McClure, and â€œranâ€ over to the vehicle in which McClure was in the driverâ€™s seat.Â  The officers testified to seeing drugs in the car as they approached the vehicle.Â  Everyone in the car was detained and searched.
McClure was indicted for possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine.Â  Although the court agreed with McClure that the search of the car and the seizure of the crack cocaine had been completed without a search warrant, the court found the evidence fell within the â€œplain viewâ€ exception.Â  After conviction by a jury, the trial judge sentenced McClure to fifteen years, plus a $50,000 fine.Â  Further, the judge revoked McClureâ€™s probation related to a previous conviction, thereby adding nine years to his fifteen year sentence.
Standard of Review
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001). Â The appellate court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings, including preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases, unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Wilson, 245 S.C. at 5, 545 S.E.2d at 829.
The appellate standard of review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is limited to determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding.Â  State v. Pichardo, 367 S.C. 84, 623 S.E.2d 840 (Ct. App. 2005). Â The trial judgeâ€™s factual findings on whether evidence should be suppressed due to a Fourth Amendment violation are reviewed for clear
error. State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 625 S.E.2d 216 (2006); see also State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 665-66 (2000) (noting a private search is a question of fact and the trial courtâ€™s ruling will be reversed only if there is clear error).Â  The appellate court may only reverse where there is clear error.Â  Pichardo, 367 S.C. at 95, 623 S.E.2d at 846.Â  The â€œclear errorâ€ standard means that an appellate court will not reverse a trial courtâ€™s finding of fact simply because it would have decided the case differently.Â  Easley v. Cromartie, 532 U.S. 234 (2001); Pichardo, 367 S.C. at 96, 623 S.E.2d at 846.Â  Rather, the appellate court must ask whether, on the entire evidence, it is left with the definite and firm conviction that a mistake has been committed.Â  Id.
An appellate court must affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling if there is any evidence to support the ruling.Â  Pichardo, 367 S.C. at 96, 623 S.E.2d at 846.
Discussion
During a pretrial hearing, McClure moved to suppress the crack cocaine and other items found in his possession on the night of April 22, 2004.Â  After the motion for suppression was heard and in camera testimony was proffered, the judge denied the motion to suppress the evidence.Â  The judge elucidated: â€œI [am] allowing it in. When it [is] offered into evidence, obviously then you can just simply make an objection, just note â€˜my objectionâ€™ and I [will] do that at the time. Make sure it [is] protected on the record.â€ Â When the evidence was later introduced, McClure did not object.Â  McClure did not object: (1) to Commander Marvin Brownâ€™s testimony concerning the drugs he found in McClureâ€™s possession; or (2) when the State entered as evidence the metal box containing drugs found in McClureâ€™s lap, the saucer found at McClureâ€™s feet, or the drugs found both in the metal box and at McClureâ€™s feet.
An in limine ruling is not final and does not preserve an issue for appeal.Â  State v. Hughes, 336 S.C. 585, 591, 521 S.E.2d 500, 503 (1999). Â An issue is not preserved for appeal if trial counsel fails to make a contemporaneous objection to the entry of evidence when the evidence is presented at trial. Â State v. Wannamaker, 346 S.C. 495, 499, 552 S.E.2d 284, 286 (2001).Â  No issue may be raised for the first time on appeal, instead it must have been raised at trial in order to preserve the issue for appeal.Â  State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 481 S.E.2d 118 (1997). Â Because McClure failed to object to the entry of evidence at the time the State introduced the evidence at trial, he is precluded from raising this issue on appeal.Â  Thus, this issue is not preserved for our review.
Conclusion
Accordingly, McClureâ€™s conviction and sentence are
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY, and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Premier Resorts International v. Sands Resorts Holdings
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Premier Resorts International, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Sands Resorts Holdings, LLC., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-261
Submitted April 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 24, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Jackson Thomas, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Mark McAdams and Amanda A. Bailey, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Premier Resorts International, Inc., appeals a grant of summary judgment to Sands Resorts Holdings, LLC, arguing the trial court erred in holding a contractual provision precluded its recovery of damages for lost revenues or profits.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
Premier is a â€œresort condominium management company.â€Â  Premier entered into an agreement (the Agreement) with Sands in which Premier agreed to manage Sandsâ€™ condominium operations in Myrtle Beach.Â  The Agreement provided for monthly compensation from Sands to Premier in exchange for management services rendered by Premier.Â  The Agreement also contained the following provisions, which are germane to the current appeal:

3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Term. The term of this Agreement shall commence on May 1, 2002 and shall continue until December 31, 2007.Â  Thereafter, this Agreement shall renew annually subject to termination by [Sands] or [Premier] upon notice delivered prior to November 1 of each year.
. . . .
10.Â Â Â Â  No Special Damages.Â  Notwithstanding any other provision hereof, neither party shall be liable for any indirect, incidental, special, consequential, exemplary, or punitive damages (including but not limited to damages for lost profits, lost revenues, or the cost of purchasing replacement services) arising out of the performance or failure to perform under this Agreement.
. . . .
19.Â Â Â Â  Termination.
. . . .
[(2)] (d) Budget Shortfall. Either party hereto may terminate this Agreement upon thirty (30) days written notice if [certain contractual budgetary and revenue-related goals] for Resort Operations [are not met] . . . .
(3) Compensation.Â  Within sixty (60) days after termination as provided herein, [Sands] shall pay to [Premier] the management fees prorated as of the termination date and its reimbursable expenses.Â  Upon such termination and payment, neither party shall have any obligation to the other for future performance under the Agreement, except that each party shall remain liable to the other with respect to performance due or owed under this Agreement . . . .

The parties agree that Sands terminated the Agreement in January 2003.Â  The parties disagree, however, about whether Sandsâ€™ termination was wrongful or in compliance with paragraph 19(2)(d) of the Agreement.Â  As a result, Premier filed a complaint against Sands for breach of the Agreement.Â  Premier sought two distinct damage awards: $196,559.09 for services rendered, and approximately $5,000,000 for lost revenue and profit based on the amount that would be due under the Agreement through December 31, 2007.Â  Sands answered, alleged that it complied with paragraph 19(2)(d) in terminating the Agreement, and averred that paragraphs 10 and 19(3) of the Agreement precluded the second type of damages alleged by Premier.Â  
Sands paid $189,836.00 to settle Premierâ€™s first damage claim for services rendered.Â  In October 2004, Sands moved for summary judgment on the second damages claim for lost revenues, arguing the express terms of the Agreement prevented Premier from recovering damages for lost revenue or lost profits.Â  Premier argued the lost revenues or profits to which it was entitled were general damages and thus outside the province of paragraph 10.Â  In addition, Premier argued paragraph 19(3) did not apply because Sands wrongfully breached the Agreement.Â  
The trial court granted summary judgment to Sands, holding the parties intended to preclude the recovery of lost revenues or profits, whether general or special damages, in paragraph 10 of the Agreement. The court further held that the lost revenues or profits alleged by Premier were special damages precluded by paragraph 10, and that paragraph 19(3) applies only to a wrongful breach.Â  Premier filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion, which the trial court denied.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court reviews the grant of summary judgment under the same standard applied by the trial court.Â  Houck v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 7, 11, 620 S.E.2d 326, 329 (2005).Â  The trial court should grant summary judgment â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 338, 611 S.E.2d 485, 487 (2005).Â  
Moreover, the construction and enforcement of an unambiguous contract is a question of law for the court and thus can be properly disposed of at summary judgment.Â  Hansen v. United Servs. Auto. Assâ€™n, 350 S.C. 62, 67, 565 S.E.2d 114, 116 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In such a case, summary judgment is proper and a trial unnecessary when the intention of the parties as to the legal effect of the contract may be gathered from the four corners of the instrument itself.Â  First-Citizens Bank & Trust Co. v. Conway Natâ€™l Bank, 282 S.C. 303, 305, 317 S.E.2d 776, 777 (Ct. App. 1984).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Premier argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment because: (1) the Agreement unambiguously states only lost revenues or profits that can be categorized as special damages are precluded; (2) the lost revenues and profits it seeks here are properly categorized as general damages; and (3) paragraph 19(3) only applies to a wrongful termination.Â  Because we disagree with Premierâ€™s first argument, we find it unnecessary to address Premierâ€™s second and third issues.
â€œIn general, if the contract is unambiguous, clear, and explicit, it must be construed according to the terms the parties have used, and the terms are to be taken and understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€Â  Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 98, 110, 531 S.E.2d 287, 293 (2000).Â  When the parties define the words or terms that they propose using, the contract will be interpreted according to such definitions if free from ambiguity.Â  C.A.N. Enters., Inc. v. S. C. Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 296 S.C. 373, 378, 373 S.E.2d 584, 586 (1988).Â  â€œThe judicial function of a court of law is to enforce a contract as made by the parties, and not to rewrite or to distort, under the guise of judicial construction, contracts, the terms of which are plain and unambiguous.â€Â  Hardee v. Hardee, 355 S.C. 382, 387, 585 S.E.2d 501, 503 (2003).Â  The duty of a court is limited to the interpretation of the contract made by the parties themselves regardless of the contractâ€™s wisdom or folly, apparent unreasonableness, or failure of the parties to guard their rights carefully.Â  Gilstrap v. Culpepper, 283 S.C. 83, 86, 320 S.E.2d 445, 447 (1984).
However, when an agreement is ambiguous, the court should seek to determine the partiesâ€™ intent.Â  Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 94, 594 S.E.2d 485, 493 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A contract is ambiguous only when it may fairly and reasonably be understood in more ways than one.Â  Goldston v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 358 S.C. 157, 170, 594 S.E.2d 511, 518 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A contract is read as a whole document so that one may not, by pointing out a single sentence or clause, create an ambiguity.Â  Southern Atl. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. Middleton, 356 S.C. 444, 447, 590 S.E.2d 27, 29 (2003).Â  Furthermore, a proper construction seeks to harmonize the various provisions, and a construction that gives meaning to all should be preferred over one which renders some provisions meaningless.Â  Hays v. Adair, 267 S.C. 291, 296, 227 S.E.2d 665, 667-68 (1976).
In this case, the trial court held â€œeven if the Court were to categorize the damages sought by Premier as general damages, the recovery of those damages have been specifically precluded by the parties.â€Â  By its express terms, paragraph 10 includes lost revenues and lost profits in the category of damages that cannot be recovered.Â  Premier contends on appeal that paragraph 10 should be read correctly as â€œneither party shall be liable for any indirect, incidental, special, consequential, exemplary, or punitive damages, including special damages for lost profits, lost revenue . . . .â€Â  However, this construction would render the parenthetical information in paragraph 10 meaningless.Â  See Hays, 267 S.C. at 296, 227 S.E.2d at 667-68.Â  We hold the Agreement unambiguously defines any claims for loss of revenue or profit as claims for special damages.Â  Therefore, the trial court properly held these claims were excluded under paragraph 10 of the Agreement.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.[1]
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Elaine Norton, Employee, Respondent,
v.
Wellman, Inc. - Palmetto Plant, Self Insured Employer,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-262
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 24, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kirsten Leslie Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
SteveÂ  Wukela, Jr., of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, Wellman, Inc., appeals a circuit court order affirming the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s decision awarding benefits to Elaine Norton, a former employee.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
At the time Elaine Norton testified in front of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, she was 62 years old.Â  Norton worked for Wellman, Inc., for thirty years in several different capacities.Â  When Norton first began her employment, her duties consisted primarily of typing reports written by other people in the company.Â  After approximately seven years, Norton began working in the purchasing department where she typed purchase orders and shipping authorizations.Â  
When the company began using computers, Norton began to do a considerable amount of keyboard data entry.Â  Due to company downsizing, for the last five years of Nortonâ€™s employment she was the only clerk working in the purchasing department.Â  Nortonâ€™s other duties consisted of filing, answering the phone, information gathering, and various other computer work.Â  
Norton testified that for approximately fifteen years she had problems with neck pain.Â  She also stated that her employer was aware of these problems and that she began seeing a chiropractor for treatment.Â  Norton received treatment from this chiropractor, Dr. Ware, for fifteen years.Â  Norton stated that during â€œthe last quarter of 2002â€ she began to develop pain in her arms between the shoulder and elbow.Â  
Because of the increasing pain and failure of the chiropractic visits to alleviate it, Norton began seeing Dr. Miller, her family physician.Â  Dr. Miller conducted several tests on Norton including an MRI on the upper portion of her body.Â  After receiving the results of these tests, Dr. Miller suggested Norton cease working and she was placed on medical leave on February 4, 2003.Â  
After several visits to Dr. Miller, Norton was referred to Dr. Healeyâ€”a neurologist.Â  Dr. Healey also performed a number of tests on Norton including, inter alia, another MRI and a test for carpel tunnel syndrome on June 12, 2003.Â  Dr. Healeyâ€™s tests revealed a number of medical problems.Â  For instance, Dr. Healey testified that Norton suffered from a sleep disorder, depression, and degenerative changes in her spine.Â  When questioned as to whether Nortonâ€™s spinal problems were caused by her duties at Wellman, Inc., Dr. Healey testified that he believed her work did contribute to the problems she was having.Â  
Dr. Healey also testified the carpal tunnel test revealed moderately severe bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome.Â  He stated with a reasonable degree of medical certainty that the carpal tunnel problems were related to the work Norton performed at Wellman, Inc.Â Â  In his deposition, Dr. Healey stated that June 24, 2003 was the first time he and Norton specifically talked about Nortonâ€™s work at Wellman, Inc. 
On July 22, 2003, Norton filed a Form 50 with the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  A hearing was held before a single commissioner on March 16, 2004.Â  In her order, the single commissioner found, among other things, â€œthe evidence supports a finding the claimant suffered compensable work related injuries bilaterally to the upper extremities and back on or about June 24, 2003. . . .â€Â  Wellman, Inc. appealed this decision to an Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.
On February 24, 2005, the panel issued an order affirming the single commissionerâ€™s order with one amendment.Â  The panel amended the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact to clarify that Nortonâ€™s injuries were to her cervical spine and not to her lumbar spine.Â  Otherwise the commissionerâ€™s order was affirmed in its entirety.Â  
Wellman, Inc. then appealed this decision to the circuit court on June 9, 2005.Â  After review, the circuit court held there was substantial evidence in the record to support the Full Commissionâ€™s February 24, 2005 order.Â  Accordingly, the court affirmed the Commissionâ€™s decision in an order dated August 5, 2005.Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
On appeal to this court, Wellman, Inc. argues the preceding tribunals erred in finding and subsequently affirming the holding that Norton injured her back and right or left arm in an accident arising out of and in the course of her employment on June 24, 2003.Â  We affirm.
The Administrative Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  In an appeal from the Commission, neither this Court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œAny review of the commissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€Â  Lockridge v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Accordingly, we limit review to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Corbin, 351 S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95.Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion that the full commission reached.â€Â  Lockridge, 344 S.C. at 515, 544 S.E.2d at 844.Â  â€œThe â€˜possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€™â€Â  Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984)).
Significantly, â€œ[t]he Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases and is not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.â€Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 517, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Accordingly, the appellate panel has the final determination of witness credibility and also determines the weight to be accorded evidence.Â  Id.Â  In the current case, after â€œcareful review,â€ the Commission found all of the hearing commissionerâ€™s Findings of Fact and Rulings of Law were correct as stated with the exception of the aforementioned amendment.Â  As such, the Commission adopted the hearing commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and rulings of law by reference into its final order as it is entitled to do under sections 42-17-40 and 1-23-350 of the South Carolina Code.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 42-17-40 (Supp. 2005) & 1-23-350 (2005); see also Eaddy v. Smurfit-Stone Container Corp., 355 S.C. 154, 167-168, 584 S.E.2d 390, 397-398 (Ct. App. 2003) (interpreting these statutory provisions and concluding the Commission meets the requirements contained therein when it incorporates a single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and rulings of law by reference into its order).
As noted previously, Wellman, Inc. takes exception to the finding that Norton was injured in an accident arising out of her employment on June 24, 2003.Â  Wellman, Inc. is particularly concerned with the specific date of June 24, 2003, because it takes the position that since Norton ceased working in February 2003, it would be impossible for her to injure herself in an accident arising out of or in the course of her employment in June 2003.
However, it is apparent from all of the previous orders issued in this case, including the circuit court order, that June 24, 2003, was the date Norton was diagnosed with conditions related to her employment with Wellman, Inc.Â  Dr. Healey specifically testified he did not talk to Norton about her duties at Wellman, Inc. until June 24, 2003.Â  It was on that date Dr. Healey attributed Nortonâ€™s problems to her employment.Â  
As noted by the circuit court, a repetitive trauma injury such as carpal tunnel syndrome is compensable under workersâ€™ compensation law.Â  Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 474, 617 S.E.2d 369, 380 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Furthermore, it is clear that a claimant must give notice of his injuries â€œwhen the employee becomes disabled and could discover with reasonable diligence his condition is compensable.â€Â  Id. at 481, 617 S.E.2d at 383.Â  
Norton did not find out her health problems were causally related to her employment until June 24, 2003.Â  Shortly thereafter, she filed a Form 50 on July 22, 2003, which, as the circuit court noted, was well within the time limit prescribed for giving notice.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (1985) (delineating standards for providing notice of accidents covered by workersâ€™ compensation).Â  Accordingly, we find Wellman, Inc.â€™s appeal to be without merit. 
AFFIRMED.[1]
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
