title: Richardson v. Fairfield County
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Joseph Richardson, Katherine Mosley Morrison and William E. Mosley, Plaintiffs, of whom Joseph Richardson is,
Appellant,
v.
Fairfield County, by and through the Fairfield County Council,
Respondent.
I-77 Properties, LLC, Intervenor.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-263
Heard April 6, 2006 â€“ Filed May 24, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph Richardson, of Columbia, pro se.
Peter D. Protopapas, Keith M. Babcock, A. Camden Lewis, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Joseph Richardson brought suit against Fairfield County for injuries resulting from a purported violation of the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).Â  The trial court dismissed Richardsonâ€™s suit for mootness.Â  Richardson appeals the order, arguing the trial court erred: Â (1) in dismissing the action after granting leave to amend the complaint; (2) in dismissing the action when relief having a practical legal effect on the existing controversy was available; and (3) in the alternative, finding the â€œpublic importanceâ€ exception to the mootness doctrine did not apply.Â  We affirm. Â 
FACTS
On April 22, 2003, the Fairfield County Council noticed a Worksession/Special Meeting for April 23, 2003.Â  The notice included the location of the meeting, the date and time of the meeting, and an agenda for the meeting.Â  In addition, the notice listed â€œC&D Landfillâ€ under â€œItems for Discussion.â€Â Â Â  
At the April 23, 2003 meeting, the County Council voted to issue a Letter of Consistency to I-77 Properties, LLC, (Company) indicating Companyâ€™s proposed landfill was consistent with county ordinances.Â Â Â  Company needed a Letter of Consistency to comply with the Department of Health and Environmental Controlâ€™s (DHEC) then existing permitting process.Â  At that time, DHEC delegated authority to the counties to determine whether a landfill was consistent with county ordinances, one requirement for receiving a permit for a landfill.Â Â  
On May 23, 2003, Richardson filed a complaint against Fairfield County for various causes of action.Â  On July 7, 2003, Richardson filed an amended complaint adding two other plaintiffs and alleging two causes of action.Â  Richardson alleged the Letter of Consistency was issued illegally and in violation of his due process rights under the South Carolina and United States Constitutions. Â Richardson also alleged Fairfield County violated FOIA by holding a meeting without providing proper notice of the meetingâ€™s agenda.Â  Specifically, Richardson argued the notice was overly vague and requested that the court issue an injunction preventing County Council from sending the Letter of Consistency to DHEC.Â  Company intervened in the action.Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
In April of 2004, in Southeast Resource Recovery, Inc. (SRRI) v. South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, the South Carolina Supreme Court held â€œDHEC, not the county, is charged with ensuring proposed landfills meet the requirements for permitting,â€ and, thus, DHEC cannot delegate to the counties the authority to determine consistency with county ordinances through the countiesâ€™ issuance of Letters of Consistency.Â  Southeast Resource Recovery, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 358 S.C. 402, 408, 595 S.E.2d 468, 471 (2004).Â  Based on the courtâ€™s holding in SRRI, Fairfield County filed a motion to dismiss for mootness pursuant to Rule 12,
SCRCP.    
The circuit court held a hearing on the motion to dismiss on July 14, 2004.Â  At the hearing, Richardson moved to amend the complaint a second time in order to eliminate his due process claim.Â  The court granted leave to amend and then heard arguments surrounding Fairfield Countyâ€™s motion to dismiss the FOIA claim.Â  By order, the court granted the Countyâ€™s motion to dismiss for mootness.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
Richardson filed a Motion to Reconsider the Order Granting Dismissal.Â Â Â Â  The court denied Richardsonâ€™s Motion to Reconsider.Â  This appeal followed.Â  Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to grant a Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, motion to dismiss must be based solely upon the allegations set forth in the complaint.Â  Carolina Care Plan, Inc. v. United Healthcare Servs., Inc., 361 S.C. 544, 550, 606 S.E.2d 752, 755 (2004).Â  A 12(b)(6) motion should not be granted if the facts alleged and the inferences reasonably deducible therefrom would entitle the plaintiff to any relief on any theory of the case. Â Gentry v. Yonce, 337 S.C. 1, 5, 522 S.E.2d 137, 139 (1999).Â  The question is whether, viewing the allegations in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, the complaint states any valid claim for relief, even if the court doubts that the plaintiff will prevail.Â  Carolina Care Plan, Inc., 361 S.C. at 550, 606 S.E.2d at 755. 
DISCUSSION
I.                 
Dismissal After Granting Leave to Amend 
Richardson argues the trial court erred in dismissing this action after granting Richardson leave to amend his complaint.Â  We disagree.
Generally, â€œ[a]n order to amend carries with it permission to file the amended pleading.â€Â  71 C.J.S. Pleading Â§ 423 (2000).Â  â€œPermission to amend the complaint contemplates an amendment which will cure the defects of the pleading without changing the essential basis of the cause of action which it originally attempted to set out.â€ Id.Â  The amended pleadings must be in conformity with the order to amend.Â  Id.Â  
Initially, we find this issue is not preserved for review.Â  At the hearing, the trial court granted Richardson â€œleave to amend the complaint to eliminate the first cause of actionâ€ and then permitted Richardson to retain the allegations contained within the first cause of action to be included in the second cause of action in the amended complaint.Â  Subsequently, without objection, the court considered DHECâ€™s motion to dismiss the FOIA claim, the second cause of action. Â Because Richardson offered no objection to this procedure, he failed to properly preserve the issue for this courtâ€™s review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œ[A]n issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 212, 479 S.E.2d 35, 41 (1996) (noting failure to object at trial waives argument on appeal); Medlock v. One 1985 Jeep Cherokee VIN 1JCWB7828FT129001, 322 S.C. 127, 132, 470 S.E.2d 373, 376 (1996) (recognizing a contemporaneous objection is required to preserve an issue for appellate review). Â Furthermore, Richardsonâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion, arguing the trial court erred in ruling on the issue of mootness before Richardsonâ€™s second amended complaint could be filed, is not sufficient to preserve this issue.Â  See Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995) (stating, â€œ[a] party cannot for the first time raise an issue by way of a Rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trialâ€).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In any event, this issue fails on the merits.Â  After granting leave to amend pleadings, the trial court may still rule on a motion to dismiss pleadings that are unaffected by the leave to amend.Â  See Skudowitz v. Basha et. al., 106 S.C. 541, 544, 91 S.E. 868, 868 (1917) (recognizing trial court has discretion to grant partyâ€™s motion to amend pleadings at any stage in the trial â€œeven though it might have been necessary to withdraw the case from the jury and continue it, to prevent prejudice to the opposite partyâ€) (emphasis added); cf.
Shah v. Richland Memâ€™l Hosp., 350 S.C. 139, 147-51, 564 S.E.2d 681, 685-87 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding the trial court erred in failing to grant leave to amend pleadings to add additional party but upholding the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of one of plaintiffâ€™s claims due to mootness).Â  
Moreover, even assuming a procedural abnormality, we fail to see how Richardson was prejudiced by the courtâ€™s decision to rule prior to a formal amendment to the pleadings.Â  In amending his complaint during the hearing, Richardson did not add any new causes of action, but instead, eliminated the first cause of action and retained the FOIA claim along with any relevant allegations that were part of the first cause of action. Moreover, Richardson was then permitted to argue the merits of the FOIA claim.Â  Thus, the court and the parties were cognizant of the substance of the remaining cause of action and any related issues. Â See Rule 15(b), SCRCP (â€œWhen issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent of the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had been raised in the pleadings.Â  Such amendment of the pleadings as may be necessary to cause them to conform to the evidence and to raise these issues may be made upon motion of any party at any time, even after judgment; but failure so to amend does not affect the result of the trial of these issues.â€); see also Parker v. Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer Dist., 362 S.C. 276, 286, 607 S.E.2d 711, 716 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œThe prejudice Rule 15 envisions is a lack of notice that the new issue is going to be tried, and lack of opportunity to refute it.â€); Ball v. Canadian Am. Express Co., 314 S.C. 272, 275, 442 S.E.2d 620, 622 (Ct. App. 1994) (discussing Rule 15, SCRCP and stating â€œ[p]rejudice occurs when the amendment states a new claim or defense which would require the opposing party to introduce additional or different evidence to prevail in the amended actionâ€).Â Â  
II.              
Mootness 
Richardson contends the trial court erred in dismissing the FOIA claim as moot.Â  We disagree. 
The court â€œwill not pass on moot and academic questions or make an adjudication where there remains no actual controversy.â€Â  Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 552, 590 S.E.2d 338, 349 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œA case becomes moot when a judgment, if rendered, would have no practical legal effect upon the existing controversy, thus making it impossible for the reviewing court to grant effectual relief.â€Â  State v. Passmore, 363 S.C. 568, 581, 611 S.E.2d 273, 280 (Ct. App. 2005).
Richardson asserts his claim is not moot because the court may provide equitable relief that remedies the injury caused by the County Councilâ€™s purported FOIA violation. Â Admittedly, for violations of FOIA, â€œ[t]he court may order equitable relief as it considers appropriate.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-100(a) (1991).Â  Based on section 30-4-100(a), Richardson argues the court could invalidate the County Councilâ€™s Letter of Consistency which may still be considered by DHEC, issue an order that would â€œrestore to their full lawful condition [Richardsonâ€™s] and the publicâ€™s statutory rights under FOIA,â€ or order some other equitable relief.Â Â Â  
We find Richardson waived any right to an order invalidating the Letter of Consistency.Â  At the hearing, Richardson admitted the relief originally requested, to undo the Letter of Consistency, was no longer available.[1]Â  Â Â When asked by the court what relief Richardson sought, counsel responded, â€œ[t]he relief that I had asked for, your honor, was to undo the letter of consistency.Â  Obviously, we canâ€™t do that with S.R.I. [sic].â€Â  Based on this statement, we find Richardson abandoned his claim by failing to present any argument to the trial court. Â See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œ[A]n issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); In the Interest of Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004)(stating â€œthe trial court must be given an opportunity to resolve the issue
before it is presented to the appellate courtâ€).Â  
Additionally, Richardsonâ€™s motion pursuant to Rule 59(e) did not preserve the issue.Â  First, Richardson could not use his motion to raise an issue which could have been presented to the court during the hearing.Â  Secondly, and more significantly, Richardson abandoned the issue at trial.Â  Finally, the trial court summarily denied the motion without specifically ruling on whether an order invalidating the Letter of Consistency would have a practical legal effect on the existing controversy. Â Without a specific ruling, this court is unable to review any alleged error in the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  See Patterson, 318 S.C. at 185, 456 S.E.2d at 437 (â€œA party cannot for the first time raise an issue by way of a Rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trial.â€);
Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 460, 535 S.E.2d 438, 444 (2000) (stating a trial judgeâ€™s general ruling is insufficient to preserve a specific issue for appellate review).Â  
Even on the merits, we find any other judgment that the court may render in Richardsonâ€™s favor, other than a judgment effecting the disposition of the Letter of Consistency, would have no effect on the existing legal controversy.Â  Indeed, at the hearing, Richardson suggested one possible remedy that the court could fashion would be to order the county to revise their notice procedures but admitted this remedy was solely to protect citizens in future situations.Â  Also, in his brief, Richardson suggests the court could issue an order enjoining the Council from future FOIA violations or issue an injunction that the Council alter its notice methods to ensure future compliance with the law.Â  Richardsonâ€™s suggested remedies and any other remedy the court could fashion would have no effect on the existing legal controversy, the Councilâ€™s issuance of a Letter of Consistency for Companyâ€™s proposed landfill.Â  To the contrary, the suggested remedies and any judgment other than a judgment affecting the disposition of the Letter of Consistency would only affect future situations.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly dismissed Richardsonâ€™s claim as moot.Â  See In re Chance, 277 S.C. 161, 161, 284 S.E.2d 231, 231 (1981) (recognizing South Carolina appellate courts have â€œconsistently refrainedâ€ from issuing purely advisory opinions).Â  
III.          
Public Importance Exception to Mootness Doctrine 
In the alternative, Richardson alleges that if his claim is deemed moot, the trial court erred in failing to apply the â€œpublic importanceâ€ exception to the mootness doctrine.Â  We disagree. 
Under the â€œpublic importanceâ€ exception to the mootness doctrine an â€œappellate
court may decide questions of imperative and manifest urgency to establish a rule for future conduct in matters of important public interest.â€Â  Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 568, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001).Â  â€œThe determination whether a particular suit raises â€˜questions of imperative and manifest urgencyâ€™
must be decided on an individual basis.â€Â  Sloan v. Greenville County, 361 S.C. 568, 570-71, 606 S.E.2d 464, 466 (2004) (quoting Curtis, 345 S.C. at 568, 549 S.E.2d at 596).Â  Generally, the â€œpublic importanceâ€ exception is applied in a â€œlimited nature.â€Â  Sloan, 361 S.C. at 571, 606 S.E.2d at 466.
Â This case does not fall under the â€œpublic importanceâ€ exception because there is no imperative or manifest urgency in ordering compliance with FOIA or ordering the Council to revise the notice procedures.Â  Furthermore, there is no evidence in the record to indicate that the alleged vagueness of the meeting notices was a recurring problem.Â  The question of the vagueness of the notice is subject to repetition, but will not usually become moot before it can be reviewed.Â  Thus, whenever the Council commits a violation of FOIA in the future, a citizen may then bring an action to remedy the specific injury caused by the violation.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in refusing to apply the â€œpublic importanceâ€ exception to the mootness doctrine in this case. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the trial court did not err in dismissing Richardsonâ€™s claim as moot.Â  The decision of the trial court is accordingly
 AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We note Richardsonâ€™s admission may be in error.Â  The Supreme Courtâ€™s ruling in SRRI may only limit DHECâ€™s reliance on a countyâ€™s Letter of Consistency and may not dispel DHECâ€™s consideration of such letters.Â  However, we make no determination of SRRIâ€™s effect on Letters of Consistency because we find the issue is not preserved.Â

title: MIT v. IGT
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
MIT, Inc., Appellant,
v.
IGT, aka, IGT-North America and Collins Music Company,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Jasper County
Â James S. Gibson, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-264
Heard March 7, 2006 â€“ Filed May 24, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Darrell Thomas Johnson, Jr., and Warren Paul Johnson, of Hardeeville, for Appellant.
H. Fred Kuhn, Jr., of Beaufort, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  MIT, Inc., appeals the special refereeâ€™s finding that MIT failed to prove damages in its claim against Collins Entertainment (aka Collins Music Company) under the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA).Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
The South Carolina video poker gaming industry was initiated on July 1, 1993, when the South Carolina Video Game Machines Act went into effect.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-21-2770 (Supp. 1998).Â  At that time and for all times relevant to this case, IGT was the preeminent manufacturer of video poker gaming machines, and Collins Entertainment was IGTâ€™s exclusive distributor in South Carolina.Â Â  
In April of 1993, Oscar Tysinger purchased ten IGT Playerâ€™s Choice machines for $62,947.50 from Fred Collins, salesperson for Collins Entertainment.Â  Around May of 1993, Tysinger formed MIT with Walter McGee and Henry Ingram. Â MIT operated and owned video poker machines in various locations throughout South Carolina.Â  All tolled, at the time of formation, MIT owned approximately thirty Playerâ€™s Choice machines (McGee owned twenty machines prior to formation).Â  MIT acquired additional used Playerâ€™s Choice machines from both Collins and others over time.Â  The trial court found MIT paid a total of $200,000 for the machines.Â Â Â Â  
On January 23, 1995, the South Carolina Supreme Court declared that video gaming machines with rolling screens that randomly stopped and awarded the player additional games based on winning combinations of words were slot machines and, thus, illegal in South Carolina.Â  State v. Four Video Slot Machines, 317 S.C. 397, 400, 453 S.E.2d 896, 898 (1995).Â  The decision rendered operation of the Playerâ€™s Choice machines illegal because the machines contained two rolling slot games.Â Â Â Â Â  
After the Supreme Courtâ€™s decision, Tysinger asked Collins to remove the prohibited games from the machines.Â  Collins eventually provided Tysinger with a microchip that stopped the rolling games.Â  However, the microchip had a â€œglitchâ€:Â  the microchip not only stopped the rolling games, but also stopped one of the three card games originally on the machine, reduced the payout schedule, and caused the machine to misrepresent the payouts.Â  As a result of Collinsâ€™ alterations, the percentage pay table on the machines was reduced from ninety-six percent or ninety-eight percent to ninety-two percent, causing the machines to retain approximately three times as much of the playerâ€™s money.Â  Collins allegedly requested the ninety-two percent pay table change, and the requested change was confirmed by IGT.Â Â  In time, Collins fixed the machines so the original three card games could be played; however, Collins did not correct the reductions to the payout schedule.Â  The changes to the machinesâ€™ payout schedules allegedly reduced MITâ€™s profits because players were less willing to play machines with reduced odds for winning.Â  
After receiving numerous complaints from customers, Tysinger asked Collins for a program that would take the illegal rolling games off but leave everything else exactly as it was.Â  Collins informed Tysinger that IGT had â€œhis hands tied.â€Â  IGT informed Tysinger they could supply such a program, but any order must come from Collins with a detailed explanation of the desired objectives.Â  Tysinger asked Collins to order the curative program from IGT, but Collins failed to provide any curative microchip.Â Â  
MIT commenced this action on December 16, 1996, alleging conduct by IGT and Collins Entertainment violated the UTPA and an implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose.Â  All claims against IGT were dismissed.Â  Collins filed a motion for summary judgment on both causes of action.Â  By order dated June 6, 2003, the trial court granted Collinsâ€™ Motion for Summary Judgment on the breach of implied warranty claim but found that there was a sufficient question for the fact finder on the UTPA claim.Â  By order dated August 20, 2004, the trial court found Collins violated the UPTA but MIT failed to prove damages.Â  MIT appeals the trial courtâ€™s finding of no damages and its failure to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn an action at law, tried without a jury, the appellate court standard of review extends only to the correction of errors of law.â€Â 
Okatie River, L.L.C. v. Southeastern Site Prep., L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 S.E.2d 468, 472 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Kiriakides v. Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc., 338 S.C. 572, 580-81, 527 S.E.2d 371, 375 (Ct. App. 2000), affâ€™d as modified, 343 S.C. 587, 541 S.E.2d 257 (2001).Â  â€œThe judgeâ€™s findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action,â€ whether the findings are made with or without a reference.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.                 
Damages 
MIT contends the trial court erred in finding MIT failed to prove damages proximately caused by Collinsâ€™ conduct.Â  MIT asserts it suffered a property loss valued at $200,000 due to Collins Entertainmentâ€™s UTPA violation.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
â€œ[T]o recover pursuant to the UTPA one must prove each of the following three elements by the greater weight or preponderance of the evidence: 1) a violation of the Act, 2) proximate cause, and 3) damages.â€Â 
Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 318 S.C. 471, 482, 458 S.E.2d 431, 438 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Section 39-5-140(a) of the South Carolina Code (1985) provides:Â Â Â  

Any person who suffers any ascertainable loss of money or property, real or personal, as a result of the use or employment by another person of an unfair or deceptive method, act or practice declared unlawful by Â§ 39-5-20 may bring an action individually, but not in a representative capacity, to recover actual damages.Â  If the court finds that the use or employment of the unfair or deceptive method, act or practice was a willful or knowing violation of Â§ 39-5-20, the court shall award three times the actual damages sustained and may provide such other relief as it deems necessary or proper.Â  Upon the finding by the court of a violation of this article, the court shall award to the person bringing such action under this section reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.

The only issue relevant to this appeal is whether MIT proved Collins Entertainmentâ€™s conduct proximately caused MIT to suffer damages cognizable under the UTPA.Â  MIT argues they suffered an ascertainable loss of $200,000, the purchase price of the Playerâ€™s Choice machines, because Collins Entertainmentâ€™s conduct rendered the machines worthless.Â  The contention that the machines were valueless is based on Collinsâ€™ testimony, which reads as follows:Â  

Q:Â Â Â Â Â  If Mr. Tysinger comes to you and says â€œMr. Fred, Iâ€™ve got these twenty IGT Playerâ€™s Choice machines you sold me, I need to get them out of my way, what will you give me for them, what would they be worth?â€
A:Â Â Â Â Â  To me?
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Uh-huh (Affirmative response).
A:Â Â Â Â Â  I wouldnâ€™t pay him anything.Â  I might haul them away for him but I wouldnâ€™t pay him anything because I canâ€™t use them.Â  I canâ€™t sell them.Â  I canâ€™t operate them.Â  

The special referee interpreted Collinsâ€™ testimony as referring â€œto the value of the machines as of March 26, 1999, and not at the time MIT purchased the machines,â€ and found the record indicated MITâ€™s machines were not valueless.Â  The referee also found the true measure of damages was lost profits.Â  
We agree with the special refereeâ€™s conclusion that the machines were not valueless.Â  Collinsâ€™ statement can reasonably be interpreted as referring to the value of the Playerâ€™s Choice machines at the time the question was asked.Â  Collins was questioned in 1999 and was not asked to estimate the value of the machines at an earlier date.[1]Â  Moreover, the record indicates the machines clearly had some value after Collins altered the pay table.Â  In fact, MIT was able to make a considerable profit from several Playerâ€™s Choice machines in 1997, about two years after Collinsâ€™ initial alterations.Â  Five machines supplied and owned by MIT earned a net profit of $88,281.75 during the quarter ending June 30, 1997; a net profit of $57,391.69 during the quarter ending September 30, 1997; and a net profit of $65,694.66 during the quarter ending December 31, 1997.Â  Thus, at least some of MITâ€™s Playerâ€™s Choice machines remained in operation despite the â€œglitchâ€ and were quite profitable.Â Â Â  
The record also indicates that despite MITâ€™s complaint regarding the payout schedule, MIT continued to use the Playerâ€™s Choice machines.Â  MIT did not replace them with better machines until the licenses for the Playerâ€™s Choice machines ran out.Â  This evidence supports a finding that the machines were not valueless; a reasonable business person would not continue to use a valueless product until the license ran out but would rather replace or discard the product immediately.Â  
Further, we agree with the special refereeâ€™s finding that the most appropriate method for calculating damages in this action was demonstrating a difference in profits between the original Playerâ€™s Choice machines and the machines as altered.Â  MITâ€™s UTPA claim is based on Collins Entertainmentâ€™s tampering with the payout schedule on the machines.Â  Thus, the true measure of damages is the lost profits suffered by the reduction in play based on the lowered pay tables.Â  Indeed, Tysinger admitted he was trying to prove the damages suffered in the form of the difference in profits â€œfrom the time [the machines] got malfunctioned.â€Â  However, in a response to an interrogatory sent to MIT by Collins, MIT waived damages beyond the purchase price because they were â€œunable to articulate a lost income figure.â€Â  MIT also specified at oral argument before this court that it was waiving all claims of lost profits.Â  
There was evidence in this case to support the special refereeâ€™s findings that MITâ€™s Playerâ€™s Choice machines were not without value after receiving Collinsâ€™ chip and that the true measure of damages in this case was lost profits.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the refereeâ€™s finding that MIT failed to prove the element of actual damages because MIT failed to prove how Collinsâ€™ conduct reduced the value of the Playerâ€™s Choice machines.Â  
II.              
Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
MIT argues the trial court erred in failing to award attorneyâ€™s fees despite finding Collinsâ€™ conduct violated the UTPA.Â  We disagree.Â  
This issue is not preserved for review.Â  â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â  An issue is not preserved where the trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument and the appellant does not move to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 502, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œIn other words, the trial court must be given an opportunity to resolve the issue before it is presented to the appellate court.â€Â 
In re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004).Â  The trial court did not address the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees in its order, and no Rule 59(e) motion was filed by MIT; thus, this issue is not preserved for review.Â  
On the merits, MIT is not entitled to an award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Section 39-5-140(a) provides: â€œUpon the finding by the court of a violation of [the UTPA], the court shall award to the person bringing such action under this section reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-140(a) (1985)(emphasis added).Â  A person who â€œmay bring an action . . . to recover actual damagesâ€ under section 39-5-140(a) is â€œ[a]ny person who suffers an ascertainable lossâ€ as a result of an UTPA violation.Â  MIT failed to prove any ascertainable loss and, thus, does not qualify as a person bringing an action under this article.Â  Therefore, MIT is not entitled to an award of attorneyâ€™s fees. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the record supports the trial courtâ€™s finding that MIT failed to prove the element of damages.Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision is accordingly
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â Â  

[1] Even if Collinsâ€™ testimony refers to the value of the Playerâ€™s Choice machines immediately after Collinsâ€™ alterations, his opinion is not dispositive.Â  Simply because the machines had no value to Collins does not necessarily mean they were valueless to all.Â  Considering Collins owned a large quantity of Playerâ€™s Choice machines and that Playerâ€™s Choice machines were â€œno longer being playedâ€ partly because Pot Oâ€™ Gold, a new machine, â€œput them out of business,â€ it is easy to understand why Collins would opine that the Playerâ€™s Choice machines were valueless to him.Â Â Â

PER CURIAM:Â  In this appeal, Appellants contend the Master-in-Equity erred in finding that they do not possess a prescriptive easement over the property which is the subject of this appeal.Â  We affirm.[1]Â Â  
FACTS
The real property which is the subject of this action is located in Charleston County, and consists of a parcel of land formerly owned and utilized by various railroad companies as a bed for their tracts. The subject property runs through various parcels of land owned by numerous individuals including the properties of the heirs of Louis Brown (Brown Heirs) and the heirs of Robert Lowry (Lowry Heirs). Sometime prior to October 1992, the railroad tracks were removed and the use of the property for the operation of a railroad was discontinued. Jessie Brown (Brown) contacted CSX Transportation, Inc., the owner of the property, and inquired about purchasing the land. In October of 1992, CSX executed and delivered to Brown a quitclaim deed to the subject property.Â Â  
Brown commenced this action in April 2002, to establish that he holds fee simple absolute title to the property.Â  Both the Brown Heirs and the Lowry Heirs filed Answers, Counterclaims and Cross Claims.Â  The Brown Heirs contended CSX did not have the authority to transfer the property to Brown based on the deed from Louis Brown to CSXâ€™s predecessor and that title to the property reverted to them upon CSXâ€™s discontinuance of its use for tract purposes.Â  The Lowry Heirs contended they possess ingress/egress rights over the property by virtue of a prescriptive easement.Â  Â Â 
The case was referred to the Master-in-Equity. The master ruled the Brown Heirs and the Lowry Heirs did not possess ownership rights nor did they have an easement by prescription over the abandoned railroad-bed claimed by Brown.Â  Furthermore, the master held Brown owns the subject property in fee simple by virtue of the quit-claim deed from CSX, and that the Brown Heirs and Lowry Heirs have no right to use the subject property. The Lowry Heirs filed a Notice of Appeal regarding the issue of prescriptive easement.Â  The Brown Heirs appealed the issue of a potential reverter, which was dismissed by this court. Therefore, only the Lowry Heirsâ€™ (hereinafter â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal is before us.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of the existence of an easement is an action at law. Slear v. Hanna, 329 S.C. 407, 410, 496 S.E.2d 633, 635 (1998); Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 416, 503 S.E.2d 191, 200 (Ct. App. 1998). Establishing the existence of an easement is a question of fact in a law action. Jowers v. Hornsby, 292 S.C. 549, 551, 357 S.E.2d 710, 711 (1987). Accordingly, our scope of review is limited to correction of errors of law, and we will not disturb the masterâ€™s factual findings that have some evidentiary support. Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants contend they possess an easement by prescription over the subject property.Â  We disagree.Â  
In order to establish an easement by prescription a party must show: (1) the continued and uninterrupted use or enjoyment of a right for a full period of twenty years; (2) the identity of the thing enjoyed; and (3) that the use or enjoyment was adverse or under claim of right. Horry County v. Laychur, 315 S.C. 364, 367, 434 S.E.2d 259, 261 (1993); Babb v. Harrison, 220 S.C. 20, 24-25, 66 S.E.2d 457, 458 (1951); Hartley v. John Wesley United Methodist Church of Johns Island, 355 S.C. 145, 150, 584 S.E.2d 386, 388 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The party claiming a prescriptive easement has the burden of proving all elements. Morrow v. Dyches, 328 S.C. 522, 527, 492 S.E.2d 420, 423 (Ct. App. 1997); Babb v. Harrison, at 20, 66 S.E.2d at 458 (stating that the claimant â€œcarries with her the burden of proving that the use of such disputed area was adverse for the full period of twenty years in order to establish an easement by prescription.â€). 
Appellants fall short of establishing a prescriptive easement.Â  The evidence offered by Appellants does not establish the requisite twenty year continuous use.Â  None of the witnesses were able to state with any certainty when the railroad ceased operation, nor did any witness offer direct testimony establishing the length of time the railbed had been used by them to access their property. In fact, testimony supported the opposite conclusion.Â  
One of the Lowry descendants stated he did not know how long he had used the road to get back to the river to fish, but estimated â€œover ten years.â€Â  Furthermore, one of the Brown descendants testified that the tracts had been removed and the railbed was overgrown when he returned from New York in 1981.Â  He further testified that when he returned in 1981, no one was using the railbed to access their properties except Jessie Brown.Â Â  
There was no clear evidence presented that showed continuous use of the property for twenty years.Â  At best, the testimony presented supports sporadic use for access to hunt, crab or fish for an unknown time frame.Â Â  Further, any use by Appellants was interrupted.Â  An attempt to prevent others from crossing the property constitutes an interruption, however brief, in the use and enjoyment of that property to prevent acquisition of an easement by prescription.Â  See Pittman v. Lowther, 355 S.C. 536, 540, 586 S.E.2d 149, 151-52 (Ct. App. 2003).Â Â  The testimony showed Jessie Brown erected a chain across the roadway to create such an interruption.Â  
Not only did Appellants fail to establish a twenty year uninterrupted and continuous use of the property, they have also failed to establish the use was adverse or under a claim of right.Â  The testimony did not point to a claim that the Lowry Heirs had title to the railbed; rather, the testimony was that the railbed was the way â€œwe used to get access.â€Â  Further, there was no claim that Appellantsâ€™ use of the property was adverse to Brown. â€œEvidence establishing the mere fact of use does not necessarily equate with the evidence establishing the character of such use.â€Â  Morrow, 328 S.C. at 527, 492 S.E.2d at 424.Â  
Appellants have failed to meet their burden of proof in establishing the elements of an easement by prescription.Â  Because the masterâ€™s findings of fact have evidentiary support, we affirm his finding that no prescriptive easement exists.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the masterâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
SHORT, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J., CONCUR

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-266
Submitted April 1, 2006 â€“ Filed May 25, 2006

Donald Bruce Clark, of Charleston and Sabrina R. Grogan, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
Ernest Bartlett Altman, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Vicky Griffith appeals the family courtâ€™s order finding her in contempt for failing to pay child support through the clerkâ€™s office. We reverse.[1] Â Â 
FACTS
Griffith and Bart Altman have never been married, but have a son born May 27, 1999. Â On December 6, 2004, Altman was awarded custody of their son, and Griffith was ordered to pay child support in the amount of $45.46 plus five percent to be paid weekly through the clerk of the family court commencing on the first Friday after the Final Order was signed.Â Â  
Griffith attempted to pay child support through the clerkâ€™s office, only to be told that the clerk was â€œunable to identify reason, our docket number or any other information as to why this check was forwarded to our court.â€Â Â Â  Griffithâ€™s first payment was returned to her by the clerk. Â Â Pursuant to advice from her attorney, Griffith made the next two payments directly to Altman, who cashed the checks. 
On January 28, 2005, the clerk issued a rule to show cause directing Griffith to appear on March 9, 2005, and show cause why she should not be held in contempt of court for failing to pay $238.65 in child support payments that had become due. The sheriffâ€™s affidavit of service shows Griffith was not served with the rule to show cause until February 22, 2005. On February 23, 2005, Griffith sent a letter to the clerk explaining why she had not made the first payment, which was due on December 10, 2004, and enclosed the payment. Griffith also noted in this letter that her attorney was in contact with the clerkâ€™s office regarding proper crediting of her previous payments. Photocopies of money orders presented to the clerk at that time established that the only payments Griffith had not made were the first payment (which had been paid at the time of the contempt hearing) and the two payments she made directly to Altman.
At the contempt hearing, Altman acknowledged accepting these two payments but stated that they were â€œfor another debt that she owed me,â€ which he claimed Griffith was required to pay him under the terms of the Final Order. Griffith testified she did not owe Altman any money. No evidence was offered by Altman that the two payments he accepted from Griffith, which substantially coincided with the due dates and amounts of the child support obligations, were to reimburse him for any monies Griffith owed him under the terms of the final order.[2] Â Â 
The family court found Griffith in contempt of court and sentenced her to ninety days in jail, which could be purged by paying the two payments to the clerk, plus paying $150 in court costs, and paying Altman twenty-five dollars for time lost from work. Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, an appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 244-45 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  A finding of contempt
rests within the sound discretion of the trial court and results from willful disobedience of a court order. Â Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 197, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989). Â â€œA trial courtâ€™s determination regarding contempt is subject to reversal where it is based on findings that are without evidentiary support or where there has been an abuse of discretion.â€
Henderson v. Puckett, 316 S.C. 171, 173, 447 S.E.2d 871, 872 (Ct. App. 1994). â€œEven though a party is found to have violated a court order, the question of whether or not to impose sanctions remains a matter for the courtâ€™s discretion.â€ Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 503, 597 S.E.2d 897, 900 (Ct. App. 2004). â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order,
based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€ Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Griffith contends the family court erred in finding her in contempt for failing to pay child support through the clerkâ€™s office where there was no evidence she had willfully violated the court order.Â  We agree.Â  
â€œThe power to punish for contempt is inherent in all courts and is essential to preservation of order in judicial proceedings.â€ In re Brown, 333 S.C. 414, 420, 511 S.E.2d 351, 355 (1998). Â Contempt results from a partyâ€™s willful disobedience of a court order. Â Smith v. Smith, 359 S.C. 393, 396, 597 S.E.2d 188, 189 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2004) (stating that a party may be found in contempt of court for the willful violation of a lawful court order). A willful act is one which is â€œâ€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires
to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€ Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)). â€œ[B]efore a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€ Widman, 348 S.C. at 119, 557 S.E.2d at 705.
â€œIn a proceeding for contempt for violation of a court order, the moving party must show the existence of a court order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with the order.â€ Â Hawkins, 359 S.C. at 501, 597 S.E.2d at 899. Â â€œOnce the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden then shifts to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to comply with the order.â€ Â Widman, 348 S.C. at 120, 557 S.E.2d at 705.Â  Furthermore, it is generally recognized that where a contemnor is unable, without fault on his part, to obey an order of the court, he is not to be held in contempt.Â  Hicks v. Hicks, 280 S.C. 378, 381, 312 S.E.2d 598, 599 (Ct. App. 1984). 
The evidence was undisputed that Griffith was unable, without fault on her part, to make these child support payments through the clerk of courtâ€™s office at the time they were due, and on the advice of her counsel, she made them directly to Altman.Â  The evidence also shows that these payments were made as child support, notwithstanding Altmanâ€™s statement that Griffith owed him money under the Final Order and that he â€œaccepted the money on that behalf.â€Â  The likelihood that the two payments Griffith made Â substantially in the amounts due and on the dates when the payments were due, were for anything other than child support is simply not supported by the evidence. 
The family court abused its discretion in finding Griffith in contempt where there was no evidence she had willfully violated the court order to pay child support.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
REVERSED.Â  
SHORT, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J., CONCUR.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2] The Final Order was not presented to the trial court.Â  Moreover, Altman never identified what provision of the order requires Griffith to pay him the sums he claims Griffith owed him.Â

Thomas Justin Finn, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellants.
Albert A. Lacour, III, of Charleston, for Respondent Paul Hopton d/b/a Coastal Concepts; Ernest Mitchell Griffith, of Beaufort, for Respondent Pelican Ventures Builders, Inc.; Howard A. VanDine, III and M. Ronald McMahan, Jr., both of Columbia, for Respondent Hurd Millwork Co., Inc.; and Charles J. Baker, III, James E. Weatherholtz, and Matthew E. Tillman, all of Charleston, for Respondent Sto Corp.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Richard N. Barnum, III and Regan Barnum brought this action against Sto Corp. and Hurd Millwork Co., Inc., alleging various causes of action arising from the construction of their home.Â  Sto Corp., in turn, served a third-party complaint against Pelican Ventures Builders, Inc. and Paul Hopton d/b/a Coastal Concepts seeking indemnification.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment in favor of all of the defendants and third-party defendants (collectively, Respondents) on the ground that a release given by the Barnums to several third parties that specifically released the third parties â€œand all other persons of and from any and all manner of actions, cause and causes of action, . . . lawsuits, . . . responsibilities, liabilities, . . . claims and demands of every kind, character and nature whatsoever . . . arising from the construction, purchase, sale, [and] remodelingâ€ of the Barnumsâ€™ home precluded any potential claims against Respondents.Â  The Barnums appeal.[1]  
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP (Under the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, summary judgment is appropriate â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€);Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997) (â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€); L & W Wholesale, Inc. v. Gore, 305 S.C. 250, 253, 407 S.E.2d 658, 659 (Ct. App. 1991) (stating at the summary judgment stage of litigation, the trial court does not weigh conflicting evidence regarding a disputed material fact and does not make credibility determinations); Bartholomew v. McCartha, 255 S.C. 489, 492, 179 S.E.2d 912, 914 (1971) (adopting the general rule that the release of one tortfeasor does not release others who wrongfully contributed to the plaintiffâ€™s injuries unless (1) it was the intention of the parties, or unless (2) the plaintiff has, in fact, received full compensation amounting to a satisfaction); Bowers v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 360 S.C. 149, 600 S.E.2d 543 (Ct. App. 2004) (stating a release is a contract that must be examined under principles of contract law, and in construing the terms of a contract, the court must first look to the language of the contract to determine the intent of the parties; we held where the terms of the release were clear and unambiguous, did not evince an intent to limit their scope to any identifiable parties, and averred the parties had entered into a final settlement that precluded forever any additional claims, we were bound by that clearly expressed intent without resort to extrinsic evidence and the partiesâ€™ intent was established as a matter of law).
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.
